PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Chickasha, Oklahoma. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 2012 Code, as supplemented through September 15, 2013, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 2012 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER 	CHT:1 
RELATED LAWS 	RL:1 
SPECIAL ACTS 	SA:1 
CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE 	CHTCT:1 
RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE 	RLCT:1 
SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE 	SACT:1 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE APPENDIX 	CDA:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CHARTER INDEX 	CHTi:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Indexes 
The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Sandra S. Fox, Senior Code Attorney, and Kellyn Wilcox, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Gina L. Snedeker, CPFA, CMC, Finance Director, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that her efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 2016-07 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF CHICKASHA, OKLAHOMA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL: 
Section 1. The Code entitled the "Code of Ordinances, City of Chickasha, Oklahoma," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 54, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before December 7, 2015, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine up to the maximum amount permitted or required by state law. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city council may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Ordinances adopted after December 7, 2015, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7 . This ordinance shall become effective April 7, 2016. 
Passed and adopted this 4 th day of April, 2016. 
	      Mayor 
 	 
ATTEST: 
      City Clerk 	
 	 
(SEAL)  
PART I - CITY CHARTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Printed in this part is the Charter of the City of Chickasha, Oklahoma, ratified by the qualified electors on October 19, 1976, adopted by the city on October 22, 1976, and approved by the state governor on January 11, 1977. The Charter is printed in substantially its original form, except that uniform editorial standards and system of style and numbering have been employed. Material in brackets indicates correction of obvious errors or editorial comment that has been added for clarity and accuracy. Amendments to the Charter are indicated by a historical notation enclosed in parentheses following the affected section. The absence of such a notation indicates that the section has not been amended since adoption. 
 
PREAMBLE 
We, the people of the City of Chickasha, Oklahoma, in order to enjoy the full benefit of home rule, do ordain and establish this Charter for the city.  
ARTICLE ONE. - NAME AND BOUNDARIES 
 
Section 1. -   
The municipal corporation, now existing and known as City of Chickasha, Grady County, Oklahoma, shall remain and continue to be a body politic and corporate and under the same name and with the same boundaries, with power and authority to change its boundaries in the manner authorized by law.  
Section 2. -   
Pursuant to the authority set forth in article one of the city Charter, ward boundaries of the city are hereby changed as hereinafter set forth, to wit: 
Ward 1. All that part of the City of Chickasha, Grady County, Oklahoma, situated south and west of the centerline of Georgia Avenue from the west city limits now existing or as hereafter enlarged or changed, thence east to the centerline of 21st Street, thence south along the centerline of 21st Street to the centerline of Tennessee Avenue, thence east along the centerline of Tennessee Avenue to the centerline of 12th Street, thence south along of the centerline of 12th Street to the centerline of Alabama Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Alabama Avenue to the centerline of the alley located in the twelve-hundred block of Alabama Avenue, thence south along the centerline of the alley to the centerline of Grand Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Grand Avenue to the centerline of 16th Street, thence south along the centerline of 16th Street to the south city limits now existing or as hereafter enlarged or changed. 
Ward 2. All that part of the City of Chickasha, Grady County, Oklahoma, situated south and east of the existing centerline of Grand Avenue from the east city limits now existing or hereafter enlarged or changed, thence west to the centerline of 4th Street, thence north along the centerline of 4th Street to the centerline of Tennessee Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Tennessee Avenue to the centerline of 9th Street, thence north along the centerline of 9th Street to the centerline of Georgia Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Georgia Avenue to the centerline of 12th Street, thence south along the centerline of 12th Street to the centerline of Alabama Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Alabama Avenue to the centerline of the alley located in the twelve-hundred block of Alabama Avenue, thence south along the centerline of the alley to the centerline of Grand Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Grand Avenue to the centerline of 16th Street, thence south along the centerline of 16th Street to the south city limits now existing or as hereafter enlarged or changed. 
Ward 3. All that part of the City of Chickasha, Grady County, Oklahoma, situated north and east of the centerline of Grand Avenue from the east city limits now existing or hereafter enlarged or changed, thence west to the centerline of 4th Street, thence north along the centerline of 4th Street to the centerline of Tennessee Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Tennessee Avenue to the centerline of 9th Street, thence north along the centerline of 9th Street to the centerline of Choctaw Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Choctaw Avenue to the centerline of North 16th Street, thence north along the centerline of 16th Street to the north city limits as now existing or hereafter enlarged or changed. 
Ward 4. All that part of City of Chickasha, Grady County, Oklahoma, situated north and west of the centerline of Georgia Avenue from the west city limits now existing or hereafter enlarged or changed, thence east to the centerline of 21st Street, thence south along the centerline of 21st Street to the centerline of Tennessee Avenue, thence east along the centerline of Tennessee Avenue to the centerline of 12th Street, thence north along the centerline of 12th Street to the centerline of Georgia Avenue, thence east along the centerline of Georgia Avenue to the centerline of 9th Street, thence north along the centerline of 9th Street to the centerline of Choctaw Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Choctaw Avenue to the centerline of North 16th Street, thence north along the centerline of 16th Street to the north city limits as now existing or hereafter enlarged or changed. 
(Ord. No. 2001-13, 12-3-2001)  
Section 3. -   
The city council shall have the power, by ordinance, to change the boundaries of the wards of said city. The city council shall in July of each odd numbered year review the ward boundaries and shall rearrange all boundaries, if necessary, to provide equal population representation in each ward and/or precinct.  
ARTICLE TWO. - CORPORATE POWERS, RIGHTS AND LIABILITIES 
 
Section 1. -   
The city shall have perpetual succession and shall own, possess and hold all property, real and personal, heretofore owned, possessed or held by the city and shall assume, manage and dispose of all trusts in any way connected therewith.  
Section 2. -   
It [the city] shall succeed to all the property rights and liabilities and shall acquire all benefits, and shall assume and pay all bonds, legal obligations, and indebtedness of said city, and by that name sue and be sued, may contract and be contracted with, plead and be impleaded, intervene, prosecute and defend in all courts and in all matters and proceedings; and shall have power to acquire property, real or personal, by purchase or otherwise, within or outside of the city limits, necessary for the public good, and to own, hold, sell, lease, convey or otherwise dispose of any real or personal property, within or outside of the city limits; may have and use a common seal and alter the same at pleasure. The city may dispose of real property with a county assessor appraised value of $25,000.00 or less by majority vote of the city council, any real property with a county assessor appraised valued at more than $25,000.00 shall require a majority affirmative vote of the electors in a special or general election. 
(Amd. No. VI, § 2; Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000)  
Section 3. -   
[The city] may receive bequests, gifts and donations of all kinds of property in fee simple, or in trust, for public, charitable or other purposes and to do all things and acts necessary to carry out the purposes of such gifts, bequests and donations.  
Section 4. -   
[The city] shall have the power, within or without its territorial limits, to construct, condemn and purchase, acquire, lease, add to, maintain, conduct and operate, water works, light plants, telephone system, power plants, hospitals, airports, transportation system, heating plants, cemeteries, parks, community buildings and convention halls, sewers, and all other public utilities or works local in use, and to do every other thing required (in whole or in part) for the use of said city and the inhabitants thereof.  
Section 5. -   
With power to purchase, in whole or in part, any existing plant, lands, franchises, or public utilities and to enforce such purchase by proceedings at law and to issue bonds in any amount upon a vote of majority of the electors at any special or general election, necessary to carry out any of said powers or purposes, and to exercise the right of eminent domain in condemnation proceedings.  
Section 6. -   
The city shall have all of the power conferred upon cities of the first class by the constitution of the state, and by the laws of the state not rendered inoperative by the adoption of this Charter, and shall have all such legislative, executive, judicial and proprietary power necessarily incident to or proper in the conduct of its business and affairs, and such as will promote the interests and secure the rights of its inhabitants and promote the general welfare, as fully as if specifically enumerated herein. The enumeration of any particular powers shall in no way limit the plenary powers above provided for said city. No law relating to cities of the first class hereafter enacted by the state shall operate as a repeal, diminution or limitation of the powers conferred upon the city by this Charter. The city especially reserves and shall have all governmental, proprietary and police powers incident or necessary and appurtenant to municipal corporations, either expressed herein, inherent or that may be now or hereafter granted by the constitution and laws of the state.  
Section 7. -   
The city shall succeed to own, possess and control all of the books, records, documents, and all other property, real, personal or mixed, together with all choses in action and claims belonging to and possessed by the said city, prior to and at the time of the adoption of this Charter. It shall be subject to and liable for all legal debts, obligations, judgments, warrants, and bonds for which said city is bound at the time this Charter shall become effective.  
Section 8. -   
All valid existing ordinances of this city not inconsistent with this Charter shall be and continue in full force until altered, amended or repealed by the legislative authority of the city, or until they expire by their own limitations. Nothing herein, however, shall legalize or validate any illegal or invalid indebtedness of the city heretofore contracted or incurred, or impair any defense against the payment of the same; nor shall the adoption of the Charter in any wise interfere with any proceedings heretofore instituted relative to the levy and collection of taxes, special assessments or levies of any nature or with any proceedings to enforce the payment of the same, and all valid and legal contracts and obligations heretofore entered into by the city shall remain in full force and effect and be completed and performed under ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Charter.  
ARTICLE THREE. - POLICE AND OTHER POWERS 
 
Section 1. -   
There is hereby reserved unto the city power to enact and provide ordinances to protect life, health, peace and property; to declare, prevent, abate, and remove nuisances, and to restrain and abate nuisances in courts of equity, preserve and enforce good order and good government; the general welfare and security of the city and the inhabitants thereof: to promote the public health, public peace, public morals, public safety, trade and commerce, and general welfare of the inhabitants of the said city.  
Section 2. -   
The council shall have the power to provide penalties for the violation of any ordinance, including fines and imprisonment or both and commit until such fines and costs are paid. Any person committed for non-payment of fines and costs, or either, while in custody may be compelled to work on the streets, alleys or public grounds at such rate per day as the council may prescribe, until such fine and costs are satisfied.  
Section 3. -   
The council is hereby authorized to provide civil service rules for all or any part of the city employees.  
ARTICLE FOUR. - CORPORATE POWERS - HOW VESTED AND EXECUTED 
 
Section 1. -   
The elective officers of the city shall consist of eight councilmen and a mayor, herein designated as city council, each of whom shall subscribe to an oath of office as provided by the constitution of the state, and each of whom shall execute bond as may be required by ordinances of said city.  
Section 2. -   
The city council of the city shall be vested with all legislative powers conferred by the Constitution and laws of the state on mayors and councils of cities of the first class, and by this Charter.  
Section 3. -   
The city council, from its members, shall appoint a mayor pro tempore, who shall act as mayor in the absence of the mayor, and in the absence of both, the city council shall designate one of their number to act as mayor, who in such case, shall have all the powers of mayor. The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the city council, and in his official capacity shall sign all ordinances, resolutions, orders and proceedings of the city council, and all warrants, bonds, bills, documents and proceedings authorized by the council, and he shall have power to administer oaths, and shall perform such other duties consistent with his office as may be imposed by the city council. He shall be recognized as the official head of the city for all ceremonial purposes, by the courts, for the purpose of serving civil process and by the governor for military purposes. In time of public danger or emergency, he may, with the consent of a majority of the city council take command of the police and maintain order and enforce the laws. The mayor will vote as a member of the city council. 
(Amd. No. VI, § 2; Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000)  
Section 4. -   
The city council shall hold a regular meeting at least once each month, the time therefore to be prescribed by resolution, for the transaction of business, and shall hold such other regular or special meetings as the city council may by resolution enact. Provided that the mayor, when in his judgment the business of the city may require a special meeting, may call such special meetings of the city council, at any time, by giving written notice to all members of the city council at least four hours before the time of the meeting; and provided further that the mayor shall call a special meeting upon an affirmative request of five of the members of the council, who shall sign and present to him a written request, stating the time and object of the meeting. All meetings of the city council and its proceedings shall be held at the council chamber of the city hall, or at some other appropriate place designated by city council, and must be open to the general public. 
(Amd. VI, § 4; Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000)  
Section 5. -   
No ordinance, resolution or motion of the city council shall become effective unless it receives a minimum of five votes, which shall represent a majority of the votes of the whole number of the council, except that any ordinance or resolution requiring a three-fourths majority shall be deemed to have passed when it has received the affirmative vote of six or more members of the council. Any reference to a vote of the council in any form, in this Charter, shall be construed as defined herein. If at any time a reduction in the council membership by any means reduces the number of the council to four members, then the city clerk shall immediately call a special election to be held on the first Tuesday following such 30 days after the occurrence of the vacancy to fill any and all vacancies, including the position of mayor, in the event that position is vacant. All persons elected under this provision shall file and be elected for the balance of the unexpired term of a specific vacant position. Council positions in each ward which have been elected in odd-numbered years shall be given Position 1, and those elected in even-numbered years shall be Position 2. All elected officers shall take office at the first regular meeting following election. No ordinance shall become effective until 30 days after its passage and publication, except for ordinances for appropriation of money, for the payment of current expenses of the city government. On any ordinances, which include an emergency clause, they shall become effective upon publication when passed by an affirmative vote of six members of the city council. 
(Amd. I)  
Section 6. -   
The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances and resolutions and entered upon the journal of the proceedings of the city council.  
Section 7. -   
The members of the city council and mayor shall receive no compensation for their services.  
Section 8. -   
The salaries and wages of all employees of the city not otherwise provided for by this Charter shall be fixed and regulated by the manager, subject to the approval of the city council, on the basis of the responsibilities and qualifications required of them. Premiums on all surety company bonds of the city employees and officers, including the mayor and councilmen [council members], shall be paid by the city.  
ARTICLE FIVE. - EXECUTIVE AND ADMINISTRATIVE POWERS 
 
Section 1. -   
The city council shall, by a majority of five affirmative votes, appoint a city manager who shall be chosen solely upon a basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, and who shall receive a salary to be fixed by the city council. His tenure of office shall be at the pleasure of the majority of the whole number of the council, and five affirmative votes shall be required to terminate employment.  
Section 2. -   
Under the direction of the city council, the city manager shall be the administrative head of the municipal government. He shall devote his entire time to the affairs of the city.  
Section 3. -   
Before entering upon his duties, he [the city manager] shall take the official oath and shall give such surety company bond as the city council may require and approve.  
Section 4. -   
The city manager shall have the special powers and duties herein enumerated and shall be directly responsible to the city council for the proper administration thereof, to-wit: 
(a)  To see that all laws and ordinances of the city are enforced. 
(b)  To appoint and remove at pleasure, subject to civil service ordinance if any be enacted, and except where otherwise by this Charter provided, all heads, subordinates and employees of all departments, such appointments and removals to be made on the basis of merit and fitness alone, all such officers and employees to be qualified electors of the city except in the event of special technical services, non-residents may be employed with the consent and approval of the city council. 
(c)  To exercise actual management, control, and supervision over all departments of the city government and to exercise all other administrative functions, except as otherwise in this Charter provided. 
(d)  To supervise and manage all public works and parks of the city and the repair and maintenance thereof; to manage and control the public utilities of the city and have general charge of the cleaning, lighting and improving of the streets, sidewalks, bridges and public grounds within and without the city, except as otherwise herein provided. 
(e)  To attend all meetings of the city council and to recommend for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. 
(f)  To prepare and submit to the council an annual budget as by this Charter and as is by law required. 
(g)  To do and perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the city council. 
(h)  In the event of absence, disability of or vacancy in the office of the city manager, the mayor shall perform the duties of city manager, in which event, the council may prescribe such compensation for the mayor so acting as they deem just. 
ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS  
Section 5. -   
The city administration under the manager shall be arranged into a police department, a health department, a fire department, a street department, a water department, and such other departments as the council may prescribe by ordinance. 
(a)  The police department shall consist of a chief of police and as many other police officers as may be provided for and required. 
(b)  The department of public health shall consist of a health officer, and such other employees as may be necessary. 
(c)  The fire department shall consist of a fire chief and as many firefighters as may be required. 
(d)  The street department shall consist of a superintendent of streets and such other employees as may be required. 
(e)  The water department shall consist of a superintendent and such other employees as may be necessary.  
Section 6. -   
Neither the mayor nor any other member of the city council shall interfere or become involved with personnel matters, or directly with the administration of the city. Any officer violating this section shall forfeit his office. 
The city manager is responsible to the city council as a whole and shall not be responsive to individual council member wishes, which contradict established policies. The city council shall establish over-all policies and guidelines under which the city manager shall be responsible for carrying out all the administrative functions of the city. 
Any council member may make suggestions or recommendations to the city manager at any time they deem necessary or appropriate on the operations of the city government.  
Section 7. -   
The city manager shall appoint a city clerk, who shall hold office at the pleasure of the city manager, and who shall have all the powers and duties now prescribed by law or ordinance except as is in this Charter provided. He shall sign all warrants, collect all city revenue and fees, and shall deposit daily with the city treasurer all city moneys collected by him from whatever source. He shall have the custody of, and be responsible for all books, papers, maps and records belonging to the city and not otherwise provided for, and shall perform all other duties that may be prescribed by ordinance. Before entering upon his duties, he shall give such surety company bond as the city council may require and approve.  
Section 8. -   
He [the city clerk] shall prepare immediately after the close of every month's business and keep on file for the information of the council and the general public, complete operating reports that show by classifications, the gross earnings, the operating expenses and the net profit or the net expense of each department separately and a combined operating report of all departments collectively, and a balance sheet must include a reasonable charge to cover depreciation of all physical property shown on the balance sheet and a charge to cover interest accrued on the investment shown on the balance sheet; such records and reports to begin and be kept and made not later than July 1, after election of first officers herein provided for.  
Section 9. -   
The city council shall provide for and require an annual audit of the accounts of the city by some certified public accountant. 
CITY TREASURER  
Section 10. -   
The city council shall appoint a city treasurer, who shall hold office at the pleasure of the council and who shall have all the powers and duties now prescribed by law or ordinance except as in this Charter provided. He shall have the custody of all moneys belonging to said city, which moneys shall be paid out only on the order of the city council. The salary of the city treasurer shall be fixed by the council.  
Section 11. -   
Before entering upon his duties, the city treasurer shall take the official oath and give such surety company bond as the city council may require and approve.  
Section 12. -   
Before any city funds shall be placed in any depository, such depository shall furnish to the city sufficient security to be approved by the city council, in an amount equal to the probable maximum balance that may be on deposit in such depository.  
ARTICLE SIX. - FRANCHISES 
 
Section 1. -   
No franchise or right to occupy or use the streets, bridges, property or public places in said city shall be granted, renewed or extended, except in the manner provided by ordinances and in conformity to the constitution of the state, and every grant or franchise of street, railway, gas, or water works, electric lights or pole franchise, or telegraph or telephone system or other public service utilities within said city, must be authorized or approved by a majority of the electors, voting thereon at a general or special election called for that purpose as provided by law.  
Section 2. -   
The city shall have the power to acquire by purchase, condemnation or otherwise within or without the city, such lands or property as may be necessary for the establishment, maintenance and operation of any public utility or to provide for and effectuate any other public purpose, and to sell, convey, encumber and dispose of the same for the common benefit; but no sale of any public utility shall be made until it shall have been authorized by a vote of the qualified electors of the city voting thereon at a general or special election.  
ARTICLE SEVEN. - REVENUE 
 
Section 1. -   
All laws of the state relating to revenue for and the fiscal management of cities are hereby made applicable to the city.  
Section 2. -   
Sections nine, ten, 26 and 27 of article ten of the constitution of the state, and the general laws of the state vitalizing said provisions of the constitution, are hereby made applicable to the city.  
Section 3. -   
Repealed in its entirety (Amendment No. VI, Section 3, Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000).  
ARTICLE EIGHT. - MUNICIPAL COURT 
 
Section 1. -   
The city shall establish by ordinance a municipal court system in conformity with the provisions of the state statutes for the creation, maintenance, and operation of a municipal court system.  
ARTICLE NINE. - ELECTIONS 
 
Section 1. -   
The election of all officers under this Charter shall be non-partisan.  
Section 2. -   
Each ward of the city will continue to be represented by two council members. Each council member shall be a resident and elector of the respective ward for which he/she seeks election. The election of mayor and council members shall be by all the qualified voters of the city. (Refer to Amendment III, 03-05-1991.)  
Section 3. -   
A qualified elector for the position of mayor or council member shall possess the same qualifications as required by the laws of the state. However, any such elector must abide by and conform to nepotism provisions provided herein in order to qualify for elective office.  
Section 4. -   
On the second Tuesday in the month of March in each odd numbered years there shall be held an election for one council member from each ward who shall hold office for a term of two years, and in each ward this council position shall be known as Position 1. On the second Tuesday in the month of March of each even numbered year there shall be an election held for the election of one council member for each ward who shall hold office for a term of two years, and in each ward this council position shall be known as Position 2. (Refer to Amendment IV, Section 4., Res. No. 91-27R, 09-26-1991.) (Refer to Amendment VII, Section 4, Ord. No. 2004-24, 11-15-2004.) 
Any candidate for the council shall be a resident and elector of the respective ward for which he seeks election, and upon election, the council member shall remain a resident of his respective ward for the full term of his office. Provided, however, that in the event of a change of the ward boundaries, which results in any council member no longer living in the ward for which he was elected, said council member shall remain in office for the full term for which he was elected as representative of that ward. The mayor shall be elected at large by all qualified electors of the city in even numbered years for a term of two years. (Refer to Amendment IV, Section 4, Res. No. 91-27R, 09-26-1991.) (Refer to Amendment VII, Section 4, Ord. No. 2004-24, 11-15-2004.)  
Section 5. -   
Any qualified elector may become a candidate for mayor or for city council seat by filing a written notice of such intent with the city clerk during the designated filing period. The filing period shall begin on the first Monday of February and shall continue for a period of three days. There shall be a filing fee assessed by the city clerk in the amount of $25.00 for each person who files for elective office and said filing fee shall not be refundable after the closing of the filing period. No candidate may withdraw his name from the ballot after the filing period has closed. (Refer to Amendment IV, Section 5, Res. No. 91-27R, 09-26-1991.)  
Section 6. -   
In any election held hereunder, the candidate for office who receives the plurality of votes cast in such election of such office shall be deemed elected. Officers elected hereunder shall take office on the first Monday in April and thereafter shall hold office for a term of two years or until their successors are elected and qualified or until there is a vacancy. In the case of a special election, as provided herein, the officers elected shall take office the first regular meeting after the election. (Refer to Amendment IV, Section 6, Res. No. 91-27R, 09-26-1991.)  
Section 7. -   
All registrational laws of the state shall be applicable to all elections held under this Charter, and only persons registered as provided by law shall be entitled to vote. All election laws of the state, including crimes, penalties, and contests, are hereby made applicable to elections held in this city.  
Section 8. -   
All special elections held in said city shall be upon the call of the mayor, for any purpose, with the concurrence of the city council with five affirmative votes, and in accordance with the terms and provisions of the constitution and the laws of the state. Special elections provided for within this Charter by the city clerk shall follow all applicable provisions of state law. The clerk shall give a 30 day public notice of election and provide for a three day filing period ending ten days prior to the election. Failure of the city clerk to comply with the provisions of calling a special election shall be grounds for immediate dismissal.  
Section 9. -   
A vacancy shall exist when the elective officer fails to qualify within 20 days after his election, dies, resigns, or in the case of the mayor, removes from the city, or in the case of a council member, removes from the ward of which he was elected, or if any elected officer is convicted of a felony or is otherwise legally disqualified as provided by statute or Charter provisions.  
Section 10. -   
If a vacancy occurs in any elected position, including the mayor or council member, the council may appoint a replacement to fill the vacant position with five affirmative votes and said appointment must be made no later than the third regular, scheduled council meeting following the council meeting in which the resignation is received. (Refer to Amendment VI, Section 10, Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000.) 
The council, if filling a vacancy for the position of mayor, may appoint an existing member of the council, vice mayor, or a citizen-at-large. (Refer to Amendment VI, Section 10, Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000.) 
If the city council is unable to fill the vacancy by five affirmative votes at the third regular meeting following the vacancy, then the city council shall be required to immediately authorize the mayor to call a special election on the first Tuesday after 30 days' public notice and a three-day filing period shall be established and shall end ten days prior to the date of the election. (Refer to Amendment VI, Section 10, Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000.) 
However, no election shall be held if 90 days exist prior to the next regular city election. (Refer to Amendment VI, Section 10, Amended Res. No. 2000-17R, 11-6-2000.)  
Section 11. -   
The city council shall have the power to pass all necessary ordinances to fully vitalize all provisions of this Charter relating to elections.  
Section 12. -   
Article 18 of the constitution of the state, under the title "Municipal Corporations," and every section thereafter, including initiative and referendum and all other provisions of said Article 18, is hereby adopted and made to be in full force and effect for the government of the city.  
ARTICLE TEN. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
 
Section 1. -   
The city council shall establish by ordinance such advisory boards and commissions as it may deem necessary. It is intended that the city council be guided in the creation of any and all such boards or commissions by the greatest good for the city, and the most efficient and effective management of the city business.  
Section 2. -   
The city council shall establish an advisory library board. The city manager shall be responsible for all employees, operations and management of the library. The library board will submit all recommendations pertaining to the operation of the library to the city manager. The adoption of these recommendations shall be subject to the approval of the city manager.  
ARTICLE ELEVEN. - PARKS 
 
Section 1. -   
All parks belonging to or under the control of the city and used for park purposes, or which may be acquired for park purposes, within or without said city, shall be under the management and control of the city manager.  
ARTICLE TWELVE. - SPECIAL IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Section 1. -   
The city shall have the power to construct or cause to be constructed special improvements consisting of curbing and guttering, grading, paving or surfacing of streets, including surface drainage of such streets and disposition of same by storm sewers, storm sewer systems constructed separately from paving, sanitary sewer systems and ornamental streetlights.  
Section 2. -   
Proceedings looking to the installation of any of the special improvements hereinabove listed in section one, and proceedings looking to the payment of said improvements by the people shall be instituted, conducted, and maintained as by the general laws of the state provided relating to cities of the first class in the state.  
ARTICLE THIRTEEN. - AMENDMENT TO CHARTER 
 
Section 1. -   
This Charter may be amended by proposal therefor submitted by the city council to the qualified electors of the city, or by petition as provided by law, at a general or special election, and when ratified by a majority of the qualified electors voting thereon, and approved by the governor, as herein provided for the approval of the Charter, such amendment shall take effect and be in force.  
ARTICLE FOURTEEN. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Section 1. -   
The city council shall require good and sufficient bonds for all contractors, with sufficient surety who shall be residents of the state, except non-resident surety and bonding companies, domesticated and authorized to transact business in the state.  
Section 2. -   
No contract shall be entered into by the city council until an appropriation has been made therefore nor in excess of the amount appropriated and all contracts shall be made upon specifications. No contract shall be binding upon the city unless it has been signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk, and the expenses thereof charged to the proper fund, liable for payment of the same, and whenever the contract charged to any fund equals the appropriation made therefor, no further contract shall be signed by the mayor or clerk, the payment of which would come from such funds.  
Section 3. -   
All contracts of whatever character pertaining to public improvements, or maintenance of the public property of said city, involving an outlay of as much as $3,500.00, shall be based upon specifications, to be prepared and submitted to and approved by the city council, and after approval by city council, advertisements for the proposed work or matter embraced in said contract shall be made, inviting competitive bids for the work to be done, which advertisement shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in said city, and all bids submitted shall be sealed, and shall be opened by the city manager or his designee with said bid opening being open to members of the public and all bidders, and the bids shall remain on file in the office of the clerk to be open to public inspection. However, if an emergency arises, the city council at its discretion by majority vote shall be authorized to make expenditures exceeding $3,500.00 without bid or advertisement therefore by declaring an emergency and said emergency shall be deemed to be a true emergency and must be vital to the health and welfare of the citizens of the city. (Refer to Amendment V, Section 3, Res. No. 96-31R, 09-03-1996.)  
Section 4. -   
All legal process against the city shall be served upon the mayor or the acting mayor in his absence.  
Section 5. -   
The property, real and personal, belonging to said city, shall not be liable to be sold or appropriated under any writ or execution or cost bill, or forced sale, nor shall the funds belonging to said city in the hand of any person be liable to garnishment for any debt it may own or funds it shall have due from any person, nor shall said city be required to answer any writ or garnishment on any account whatsoever.  
Section 6. -   
No officer or employee of said city shall give, or promise to give, to any other person any portion of his compensation or any money or valuable thing or promise of employment to any person, in consideration of having been or being nominated, appointed, voted for or elected to any office of employment, and if such promise or gift be made, the person making or accepting such gifts or promise shall forfeit his office or employment and be debarred and disqualified from being elected, appointed, or employed in the service of said city.  
Section 7. -   
Any officer of said city who shall, while in office, accept any donation or gratuity in money or other valuable thing, either directly or indirectly from any person or corporation dealing with the city, or any subordinate or employee or from any candidate or applicant for any position as employee or subordinate under him shall forfeit his office and be forever debarred and disqualified from holding any position in the service of the city.  
Section 8. -   
Neither the mayor or any member of the city council nor appointed employee of the city shall be directly in the employ of any person, company or corporation holding or seeking to hold any franchise of the city, or shall receive directly any wages, commission, gifts, or favor or payment from any such franchise holder; and any violation of this section shall render vacant, ipso facto, the position held by the person so violating it.  
Section 9. -   
No member of the city council or any other officer of the city shall be directly financially interested in any work, business or contracts, the expense, price or consideration of which is paid from the treasury or by any assessment levied by ordinance or resolution of the city council; nor surety of any person having any contract work or business with said city for the performance of which security may be required, nor be the surety on the official bond of any officer of the city. Contracts in violation of this provision shall be void.  
Section 10. -   
Every officer who shall approve, allow or pay any demand on the treasury not authorized by law, or by this Charter, shall be liable to said city individually and on his official bond for the amount of the demand so illegally approved, allowed or paid.  
Section 11. -   
All writs, subpoenas, or other process issuing out of the municipal court shall run in the name of the city, and may be executed and served by the chief of police or his deputies or police officers of said city; provided that the city shall never be liable for the cost of any proceeding in the police court, and provided further that such process shall not be served outside of the city.  
Section 12. -   
The city shall have and exercise general powers over its streets, alleys and public property and may prescribe all rules and ordinances deemed expedient for the preservation and protection thereof.  
Section 13. -   
The enumeration of general and particular powers herein shall never be held or construed to be a circumscription of or limitation upon any powers whenever or wherever elsewhere provided, fixed, given, granted, invested or implied under either the Constitution or laws of the state, it being the intention by the proposition and adoption of the Charter to reserve and confer upon the inhabitants of the city the entire right, full power and unrestricted privileged self-government, such right, power and privilege, however, to be held and exercised comfortably with and not violative of the constitution and laws of the state.  
Section 14. -   
No person may be employed by the city if related to the city manager, any member of the city council, or the mayor within the third degree by affinity of consanguinity. If any elector desires to run for elective position on the city council or for mayor of the city, they shall be declared ineligible if any existing employee of the city is related within the third degree by affinity of consanguinity to such prospective candidate.  
Section 15. -   
A quorum shall consist of five members of the city council and five members shall be necessary to conduct the business of the city. For the purposes of determining a quorum, the mayor is not considered a member of the city council.  
Section 16. -   
The office of the city attorney is hereby established and the city attorney shall be appointed and serve at the pleasure of the city manager subject to the approval of the city council on a yearly basis.  
Section 17. -   
Each council member and the mayor shall be required to regularly attend official council meetings. Any person that council seats shall be declared automatically vacant if: 
(a)  Attendance is less than 75 percent of the council meetings in any 12-month period; 
(b)  More than 50 percent of any council meetings are missed in any six-month period; 
(c)  Any four consecutive council meetings are missed. 
If any such vacancies shall occur, the council shall fill such vacancy as provisions contained with the Charter.  
ARTICLE FIFTEEN. - REMOVAL OF OFFICERS 
 
Section 1. -   
There is hereby established a procedure for the removal of an elective official of the city. Said removal shall be initiated with the filing of a petition with the city clerk containing the signatures and names of at least 25 percent of those electors who voted for the particular elective office in question in the last city council election. This petition shall contain the reasons for the removal of said official in not more than 200 words. The clerk shall see that said petition is served upon the officer and return of service shall be provided for. The officer shall then have five days after the service to reply, which said reply shall be not more than 200 words.  
Section 2. -   
Within 30 days after the filing of the reply, the clerk shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, notice to the electors for the office to be vacated, advising that a petition for recall and the reply, if any, has been filed in the city clerk's office. This publication shall further advise the electors of the ward from whence the elected official in question is from and that the electors may appear at the city clerk's office and sign forms indicating their desire that the office in question be placed up for election by the city for a period of 30 days following the publication;, the clerk shall make proper forms available for signing in her office by the qualified electors, indicating their desire that the office in question shall be placed up for election by the city. These forms shall be available during regular business hours during all business days in the 30 days following the publication. If, at the conclusion of 30 days, the clerk's office has received the signature of 50 percent of the qualified electors who voted in the last city council election for the particular office in question, then said elective office shall be placed up for election and the clerk shall declare that office to be immediately vacated and the city clerk shall immediately issue a proclamation calling an election on the first Tuesday after 30 days' public notice. A three day filing period shall be established, ending ten days prior to the election.  
Section 3. -   
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to determine the authenticity and sufficiency of the signatures on the petition. In the event that the clerk should determine that there are insufficient authentic and properly qualified signatures on the petition to meet any of the requirements described above, then said petition shall be declared null and void and of no consequence by the clerk, and a public announcement of her decision shall be made. At all times during the proceedings described herein, the petition and reply shall be opened for public inspection, and available for copying. The filing and conduct of any election hereunder shall be as in any other city election.  
Section 4. -   
Any person who has been removed from an office by the provisions of this article, or who has resigned from such office while the proceedings described hereunder were pending against them, shall be appointed to no office within the city government of the city for a period of two years after such removal or resignation.  
PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES  
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Oklahoma Municipal Code, 11 O.S. § 1-101 et seq.; municipal ordinances, 11 O.S. §14-101 et seq.; adoption and revision of codes and codes of ordinances, 11 O-S. §§ 14-108, 14-109; enforcement and penalties for violation of municipal ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-111. 
 
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Chickasha, Oklahoma," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Chickasha City Code." 
State Law reference— Codification of municipal ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-108; mandatory compilation of penal ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-109.  
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
(a)  Generally. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
(b)  Minimum requirements; conflicting provisions. In the interpretation and application of any provisions of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(c)  Liberal construction. All provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true purposes, intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. 
(d)  Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other city officer or employee to do some act or perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize such department head, officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty. 
(e)  Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
(f)  Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
(g)  Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons. 
(h)  Nontechnical and technical words. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language. Technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar or appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar or appropriate meaning. 
(i)  Titles of officers, departments, etc. Whenever any officer, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title alone, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Chickasha, Oklahoma." 
(j)  Tense. Words used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well as the past and present, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(k)  Specific terms defined. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Code, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where a different definition is specifically provided for a particular provisions and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charter. The term "Charter" means the city Charter as provided in Part I of this Code. 
City. The term "city" means the City of Chickasha, Oklahoma. 
City council, council. The term "city council" or "council" means the city council of the City of Chickasha, Oklahoma. 
Code. Reference to "this Code" or "the Code" means the Code of Ordinances, City of Chickasha, Oklahoma, as designated in section 1-1. 
County. The term "county" means Grady County, Oklahoma. 
Fee schedule. The term "fee schedule" means the schedule of city fees, rates and charges compiled and amended from time to time by the city council. 
May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. 
O.S. The abbreviation "O.S." means the Oklahoma Statutes, and such term or any other reference to the statutes of the state means such statutes as now or hereafter amended, supplemented or recodified. 
Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and" and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a formal legislative act of the city council that has the force and effect of a continuing regulation and a permanent rule of conduct or government for the city. 
Person. The term "person" extends and is applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the term "person," as applied to partnerships or associations, means the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
Resolution. The term "resolution" means a special or temporary act of the city council that is declaratory of the will or opinion of the city in a given matter and is in the nature of a ministerial or administrative act. A resolution is not a law and does not prescribe a permanent rule of conduct or government. 
Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
State. The term "state" means the State of Oklahoma. 
(Code 1972, §§ 10-1—10-3; Code 2012, §§ 10-1-1—10-1-3)  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines, notes, and references. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, not as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are intended merely to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes, Charter references and state law references that appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  All references to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions, or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions, or section of this Code, unless otherwise specified.  
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal or expiration of Code sections. 
The repeal of a Code section or ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued or any offense committed, any penalty or punishment incurred, or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. Further, when any ordinance repealing a former Code section, ordinance, clause or provision, shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former Code section, ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it shall be expressly so provided.  
Sec. 1-5. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. Charter amendments may be included in like manner. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code.  
Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Chickasha, Oklahoma, is hereby amended to read as follows: …." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Chickasha, Oklahoma, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows: …." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, with reference to the subject matter, as the case may be.  
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the city council.  
Sec. 1-8. - Prior offenses, penalties, contracts or rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. In addition, the adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code.  
Sec. 1-9. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are substantially the same as ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered continuations thereof and not as new enactments.  
Sec. 1-10. - Conflicting regulations. 
(a)  If the provisions of different chapters conflict with each other, the provisions of each individual chapter shall control all issues arising out of the events and persons intended to be governed by that chapter. 
(b)  If the provisions of different sections of the same chapter conflict with each other, the provision which is more specific in its application to the events or persons raising the conflict shall control over the more general provision. 
(c)  If any of the provisions hereof conflict, and the conflict cannot be resolved by application of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the more stringent regulation shall apply and the specific provision shall prevail over the general.  
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any rates, fees or charges consistent with this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(3)  Any ordinance or resolution consistent with this Code prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones; 
(4)  Any ordinance or resolution consistent with this Code fixing salaries of, or providing policies and programs for, providing retirement, disability or death benefits for officials, officers or employees of the city; 
(5)  Any budget ordinance or appropriation ordinance; any ordinance levying any tax; 
(6)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution; 
(7)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the city; 
(8)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(9)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision within the city; 
(11)  Any zoning ordinance or any ordinance regulating subdivisions or any ordinance regulating signs or any ordinance regulating building design standards; 
(12)  Any ordinance or resolution adopted for purposes that have been consummated; and 
(13)  Any ordinance that is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect.  
Sec. 1-12. - Code and ordinances effective outside city on property owned or controlled by city. 
All ordinances of the city now in effect within the city are hereby extended to all real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city outside the corporate limits of the city, and shall be in full effect therein, insofar as they are applicable. All ordinances of the city, which shall go into effect in the future, shall also apply to, and be in full effect within the boundaries of all said outlying real property, insofar as they may be applicable. Any words in any ordinance indicating that the effect of an ordinance provision is limited to the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed to mean and include also the said outlying real property belonging to, or under the control of the city, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1972, § 10-4; Code 2012, § 10-2-1) 
State Law reference— Jurisdiction over city property, 11 O.S. § 22-116.  
Sec. 1-13. - Separability clause; Code and ordinances. 
If a court of competent jurisdiction should hold one or more ordinance sections or a part of an ordinance section of this Code or of an ordinance passed hereafter invalid, such holding shall not affect the remainder of the Code or ordinance nor the context in which such section, sections or part of a section so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part of a section may be inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the section, sections or part of a section so held invalid. 
(Code 1972, § 10-5; Code 2012, § 10-3-1) 
State Law reference— Penalty for ordinance violations, 11 O.S. § 14-111; maximum fine allowable with no jury trial, 11 O.S. § 27-119.  
Sec. 1-14. - General penalties. 
All penalties for violation of any city ordinance and this Code shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed the maximum fine allowed by law for non-jury trials plus court costs. 
(Code 2012, § 12-1-32(B); Ord. No. 1661, 7-14-1983; Ord. No. 90-23, 9-13-1990; Ord. No. 2003-05, 5-19-2003) 
State Law reference— Penalties generally, 11 O.S. §§ 14-111, 27-104, 27-119; misdemeanor punishment, 21 O.S. § 10.  
Sec. 1-15. - Penalty, penalty assessment, court costs, lab fees. 
(a)  Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter, any other provision of this Code, or any provision of any ordinance passed after this Code goes into effect shall be guilty of an offense, or misdemeanor, and shall upon conviction be fined in an amount not to exceed the maximum penalty authorized by the Oklahoma Statutes for a municipal court not of record. No penalty shall be higher than that which has been established by state statute for the same offense. Applicable court costs, fees, costs, and assessments shall be in addition to any penalty amount assessed for an offense. Each day's continuation of an offense or misdemeanor shall be deemed a separate offense, or misdemeanor and shall be punishable as such. 
(b)  A schedule of fines is hereby established by the city council. The schedule of fines shall be set forth in section 50-284, and all subsequent amendments thereto are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. Copies of the city's schedule of fines shall be available in the offices of the city clerk and the municipal court clerk. 
(c)  Court costs for offenses or misdemeanors for violations of any provisions of this chapter, any provision of this Code, or any provision of any ordinance passed after this Code goes into effect are to be assessed in an amount not to exceed $30.00, or the maximum amount allowed by 11 O.S. § 27-126, as amended. 
(d)  The court may assess court costs for the violation of any provision of this chapter, any provision of this Code, or any ordinance passed after this Code goes into effect, even though the penalty provision may not specifically provide for court costs. 
(e)  In addition to the court costs collected pursuant this section, for every fine, deferral fee in lieu of a fine, or bond forfeiture collected by the municipal court of the city, additional local and state-mandated fees, costs, and penalty assessments shall be collected as provided in Title 20 O.S. Sections 1313.2, 1313.3, 1313.4, as amended, and as provided in other applicable state laws and in this Code. 
(f)  Any person convicted of any offense or misdemeanor who fails to pay all or a portion of any penalties, fines, fees, warrants or court costs and whose unpaid penalties, fines, fees, warrants or court costs are referred to a collection agency shall pay the collection fee in an amount not to exceed 35 percent per offense. 
(Code 2012, § 14-1-1; Ord. No. 1908, 12-10-1987; Ord. No. 2012-19, 11-19-2012; Ord. No. 2017-13 , § I, 6-19-2017)  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Employee retirement system. 
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the State of Oklahoma, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part of city employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is hereby authorized created, established, and approved and adopted, effective as of May 1, 2017, the funded Plan designated "Employee Retirement System of City of Chickasha, Oklahoma, Defined Contribution Plan," adopted here by reference. Copies of the plan are available in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2017-09 , §§ 1—6, 4-3-2017; Ord. No. 2019-33 , § 1, 12-2-2019)  
Secs. 2-2—2-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-19—2-39. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS 
 
Sec. 2-40. - Rules of order and procedure. 
(a)  Authority of council to adopt and amend. To promote the proper order and dispatch of business coming before it, the city council adopts by resolution the rules of order and procedure set forth in this section. These rules shall apply and govern all council meetings; provided, however, that the rules of order and procedure may be amended by the council as deemed necessary. 
(b)  Calling meeting to order. At the hour appointed for the meeting of the city council, the mayor shall take the chair, if present, and if he be not present, the mayor pro tem shall take the chair. He shall call the house to order and proclaim the city council to be now in session. 
(c)  Order of business. The council will then attend to business in the following order: 
(1)  Roll call of members. 
(2)  Approval of minutes of last meeting and amendments. 
(3)  Citizen and council communications. 
(4)  Approval of claims. 
(5)  Ordinance and resolutions. 
(6)  Consideration items. 
(7)  City manager discussion. 
(8)  Approval of bids. 
(9)  Adjournment. 
(d)  Voting. 
(1)  Every member who shall be present when a question is stated from the chair shall vote thereon, except the member shall not vote when the question involves a business in which the member has a proprietary interest. A member shall have a proprietary interest in a business if the business engages in: 
a.  Selling, buying, or leasing property, real or personal, to or from the municipality; 
b.  Contracting with the municipality; or 
c.  Buying or bartering for or otherwise engaging in a manner in the acquisition of any bonds, warrants, or other evidence of indebtedness of the municipality. 
(2)  For purposes of this subsection, a member shall be deemed to have a proprietary interest if the member owns more than 25 percent of the business or of the stock therein or any percentage, which constitutes a controlling interest but shall not include any such interest held by a blind trust. 
(e)  Motion procedure. No motion shall be put or debated unless it is seconded. When a motion is seconded, it shall be stated by the mayor before the debate. If the question on debate contains several distinct propositions, any member may have the same divided and each part considered separately. In all cases where a resolution of motion is entered upon the minutes of the council, the name of the member introducing the same shall be entered also. The ayes and nays upon any question shall be taken and entered upon the minutes. 
(f)  Precedence of motions. When a question is under debate, the motions in order shall be to adjourn (when not qualified), to hear the previous question, to lay on the table, to postpone indefinitely, to adjourn to a certain day, to refer and to amend. Motions shall have precedence in the order provided, the first always to be in order when the floor can be obtained for that purpose, except while the ayes and nays are being called, when the members are voting or when it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken. 
(g)  Previous question. If the previous question is moved and seconded, it shall be put in this form: "Shall the main question now be put?" If this is carried, all further amendments and all further motions and debate shall be excluded and the questions be put without delay. 
(h)  Reconsideration. A question may be reconsidered at any time with majority vote of the council. 
(i)  Suspension of rules. These rules may be temporarily suspended by majority vote of all members present; but shall not be repealed, altered or amended except by concurrence of two-thirds of all members of the council. 
(j)  Robert's Rules. All rules laid down in Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, are declared to be the rules governing this council except to the extent they conflict with the rules provided in this section. 
(Code 1972, § 1-1; Code 2012, § 1-1-1(1)—(9), (15), (16); Ord. No. 2003-04, 4-21-2003)  
Sec. 2-41. - Committees. 
(a)  Generally. All committees shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of the city council. No committees shall assume jurisdiction of any subject or exercise any authority except under extraordinary circumstances, or except such special instructions from the council delegating such authority from time to time. 
(b)  Finance committees. The city council has established a standing finance committee. The mayor shall appoint four council members to the finance committee annually as soon as practical after the council election and shall appoint the chairperson. 
(c)  Special committees.
