Pet means any animal kept for pleasure or companionship. For purposes of this chapter, pets shall include only dogs and cats. 
Pinch or prong collar means a metallic or alloy substance type collars or combination of substances that protrude into an animal's neck disrupting the nervous system or pinching the skin primarily used for obedience training. The prong collar is generally made of interlocking links, each with two blunt prongs that pinch the dog's skin when the collar is tightened and is sometimes commonly referred to as a "choke collar." 
Potentially dangerous dog or other animal means any dog or other animal that: 
(1)  When unprovoked inflicts bites on a human either on public or private property; or 
(2)  When unprovoked kills or severely injures a domestic animal either on public or private property; 
(3)  Dogs or other animals shall not be declared potentially dangerous if the threat, injury, or damage was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the dog or animal; or who was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or animal; or who has, in the past, been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog or animal; or who was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
Potentially vicious animal means an animal, when unprovoked: 
(1)  Acts as if it intends to bite a human, dog, cat, animal or livestock whether on public or private property; 
(2)  Chases or approaches a human upon a public way in a threatening fashion as if to inflict injury or serious harm; 
(3)  Demonstrates aggressive behavior, which requires a human to take defensive or evasive action to avoid physical contact with the animal. 
Proper enclosure of a dangerous dog. While on the owner's property, a potentially dangerous dog shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or structure with at least 150 square feet of space for each dog kept therein which is over six months of age, and which is suitable to prevent the entry of children and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. 
Public nuisance means any animal or animals which: 
(1)  Molest passersby or passing vehicles: 
(2)  Attacks other animals; 
(3)  Trespasses; 
(4)  Is repeatedly at large; 
(5)  Damages private or public property; or 
(6)  Barks, whines, scratches, howls, or makes excessive noise in continuous or untimely fashion. 
Reptile means a cold-blooded, air breathing vertebrate. 
Restraint means any animal secured by leash or lead or under the control of a responsible person and obedient to that person's commands or within the real property limits of its owner. 
Rodent means any relatively small mammal having a single pair of upper incisors with a chisel shaped edge. 
Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery. 
Snake means a long, slender, crawling reptile having a body with scales and no legs or feet. 
Spay means to remove the ovaries of a female dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. 
Sterilization means to spay or neuter a dog or cat. 
Tether means any rope, chain, steel cable, cordage, leash, or the like, by which an animal is fastened to a fixed object so as to limit its range of movement, to fasten or confine with or as if with a tether. Tether also means to restrain an animal by tying the animal to any fixed object, including but not limited to a house, car, tire, brick, tree, fence, post, garage, shed, etc. 
Trolley system means a single guidewire system permanently placed between two immoveable objects by which a dog is fastened to and allows free range of motion by the animal. A trolley system must be a minimum of ten feet in length and be constructed a minimum of three feet above the animals head while standing at rest. The trolley guidewire must be of a plastic coated airplane cable or its equivalent and kept taught by one or more turnbuckles. Two stops must be installed to prevent the animal from getting tangled in the ends of the guidewire. The leash itself, attaching the animal to the trolley system, must be a minimum of five feet in length and be constructed of an equal or smaller gauge plastic coated airplane cable or its equivalent. Heavily braided nylon ropes are not acceptable. The leash must then be secured to the trolley pulley. The leash itself, securing the animal to the trolley, must contain a swiveling system at both ends providing a full 360 degrees of rotation. 
Vicious animal means an animal that without provocation attacks and makes physical contact with a person, dog, cat, animal or livestock with the potential to cause harm or the infliction of serious injury. A finding that an animal has previously bitten a human being two or more times without provocation is prima facie evidence that the animal is vicious. 
Wild animal means any animal which can normally be found living in a natural state and not ordinarily tame or domesticated. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-1; Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1 4-6-2015; Ord. No. 2016-08 , § I, 4-4-2016)  
Secs. 8-2—8-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 8-21. - Animal shelter. 
The city has established a city animal shelter to be located at such place as the council shall approve. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-2; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Sec. 8-22. - Animal control officer. 
(a)  The city has created the position of animal control officer who shall enforce the provisions of this chapter, issue citations for violations, and be the keeper of the city animal shelter. 
(b)  The animal control officer is authorized to capture and impound any and all animals running at large within the city in violation of any city ordinance and to take, keep and dispose of the same as provided in this chapter, including assigning contractors to trap and dispose of wildlife animals regulated under the state department of wildlife conservation and other nuisance wildlife animals. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-3; Ord. No. 1515, § 1; Ord. No. 2014-18, § 1, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 8-23. - Citations. 
(a)  The animal control officer may issue citations for violations of this chapter directing the violator to appear in court, in accordance with the following procedure: The officer shall prepare the written citation containing the name and address of the person cited and stating when the person shall appear in court. 
(1)  Unless the person requests a minimum of ten days from the date of the citation, the time specified in the citation to appear shall be at least five days after the issuance of the citation. 
(2)  One copy of the citation shall be delivered to the person cited, and such person shall sign a duplicate written citation which shall be retained by the officer. 
(3)  The officer shall thereupon release the cited person from his custody. 
(4)  As soon as practical the officer shall cause to be filed one copy of the citation with the court specified therein. 
(b)  If a person fails to appear in response to a citation, a warrant for his arrest shall be issued, and any person who willfully fails to appear in response to a citation shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-4; Ord. No. 1515, § 1; Ord. No. 2014-18, § 1, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 2, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-24. - Right to inspect. 
The animal control officer, police officer or code enforcement officer, upon complaint of any person, may inspect any structure or place where an animal is kept, and may do so on his own initiative. The officer may issue any such reasonable directive as deemed necessary to the owner of such animal to cause such animal to be kept as provided in this chapter or in a manner so as not to constitute a nuisance. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-5; Ord. No. 1515, § 1; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 3, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-25. - Obstructing animal control officers. 
Any person who shall break in or in any manner directly or indirectly aid or assist in or counsel or advise the breaking open of any city animal shelter or who shall hinder or delay or obstruct the animal control officer and his duly authorized agent in taking up or taking to the city animal shelter any such animal, or shall destroy or mutilate any notice of sale of any impounded animal, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-6; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Sec. 8-26. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine up to the maximum permitted by state law for non-jury trials plus court costs. Each day's violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 2012, § 3-7-1; Ord. No. 1661, 7-14-1983; Ord. No. 2003-05, 5-19-2003)  
Sec. 8-27. - Animal to be confined during pendency of cruelty proceedings. 
When any complaint is filed in municipal court or a citation issued alleging cruelty to animals, then the person against whom the complaint is filed, or any person having control or custody of the animal shall deliver it to the animal control officer for confinement in the city animal shelter pending judgment of the municipal court. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-14(F); Ord. No. 1515, § 1; Ord. No. 91-5; Ord. No. 2002-13, 3-4-2002)  
Sec. 8-28. - Fees; waiver. 
(a)  License, permit, impoundment, boarding, surrender, adoption and other fees authorized by this chapter shall be in the amount established by city council. Boarding fees shall be due for any day that the animal is impounded for four hours or more. 
(b)  Fees may be waived in whole or in part by the authorized city employee for hardship or special cases involving pet owner death, owner incarceration, hospitalization of owner, to rectify adoption disputes, and for similar situations in which the best interests of all parties are served by such waiver. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-9; Ord. No. 2003-05, 5-19-2003; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 12, 4-6-2015)  
Secs. 8-29—8-59. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 
 
Sec. 8-60. - Animal licenses and permits. 
The city shall promulgate regulations for the issuance of animal permits and licenses. The license period shall be one year (12 months). Application for an animal permit shall be made at the community development office. Animal permits may be revoked by mayor and council at any time upon a determination that the public interest is not well served by continuation of the permitted activity. No person who has been connected with cruelty to animals shall be issued a permit or license. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-7; Ord. No. 1585, § 2; Ord. No. 94-12, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 4, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-61. - Livestock keeping permits; animal license not required. 
No person shall maintain livestock animals within the city limits without first obtaining a permit except that agricultural zoning districts shall not require a permit to maintain livestock. The city shall not require a license for any livestock animal. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-7; Ord. No. 1585, § 2; Ord. No. 94-12, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 4, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-62. - Pet licenses and tags. 
Any person owning, keeping, harboring, possessing, or having custody of any pet over six months of age within the corporate limits of the city shall pay an annual licensing fee for each animal as determined by the city council; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the keeping of small cage birds or aquatic and amphibian animals solely as pets. 
(1)  Written application for license shall be made to the animal control officer or his designee. The application shall include the name and address of the applicant; the size, color, breed and approximate age of the animal; and proof of current rabies vaccination and the identity of the person or entity that vaccinated the animal. 
(2)  Upon acceptance of the license application and fee, the animal control officer or his designee shall issue a durable tag on which shall be stamped the year for which issued, an identifying number and "City of Chickasha." 
All pets must wear the license tag at all times when off the premises of the owner. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-1; Ord. No. 1515, § 2; Ord. No. 1585, § 3; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 7, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-63. - Kennel licenses. 
(a)  Applicability; nonconforming kennels deemed nuisance. Any person maintaining a kennel, whether for profit or not, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter. Nonconforming kennels shall be deemed a nuisance. 
(b)  License required. No person shall own, maintain or operate a kennel within the city unless such kennel is licensed as herein provided. 
(c)  Application; fee. Application for an original or renewal license shall be made to the city clerk and shall state the name and address of the owner or operator of the kennel with the street address and legal description of the property upon which the kennel is located. The annual fee in the amount established by the city council shall be submitted with the application. 
(d)  Time for applying for renewal. Application for a renewal license must be received by the city at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the license or be considered in the same manner as an application for a new initial license. 
(e)  Proof of rabies vaccination required. The owner or operator of a kennel must show proof of rabies vaccination on all animals over four months of age when applying for a license. 
(f)  Zoning restrictions. Property where a kennel is located must meet proper zoning requirements. 
(Code 2012, §§ 3-9-1, 3-9-3; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 20, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-64. - Community development department to keep register and other records. 
The city community development department shall keep a register of all licenses and permits issued by the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. The register shall show the date of issuance of each permit or license and in whose name the license or permit is issued. The community development department shall also maintain a copy of each application and a record of the identifying numbers of all tags issued and shall make this record available to the public. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-8; Ord. No. 1515, § 1; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 5, 4-6-2015)  
Secs. 8-65—8-86. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - IMPOUNDMENT 
 
Sec. 8-87. - Unrestrained dogs and nuisance animals. 
Unrestrained dogs and nuisance animals shall be taken by the police or animal control officers and impounded in an animal shelter and there confined in a humane manner. In addition to or in lieu of impounding the animal, the animal control officer or police officer may issue to the known owner of such animal a citation of ordinance violation. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-6; Ord. No. 1515, § 2)  
Sec. 8-88. - Records to be maintained. 
The animal control officer shall keep a record providing a description of all animals impounded by him, showing the date impounded, the date of sale or other disposition, the amount realized for such animal and the name of the purchaser and owner. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-11; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Sec. 8-89. - Time period for holding; redemption; disposal of ill or injured animals. 
(a)  Upon impounding an animal, the animal control officer shall attempt to notify the owner, if known to the officer, or if the owner's identity can be determined from information on tags or chips or otherwise provided to the officer. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, an impounded animal shall be held for 72 hours during which time it may be redeemed by the owner after showing proof of ownership. During the 72 hour holding period, no animal may be destroyed or adopted, except that if the animal is ill or injured to the extent that keeping it alive during the holding period would cause needless suffering and pain, the animal shall be humanely destroyed. The decision to destroy an ill or injured animal shall be made by the animal control officer or a licensed veterinarian who shall document the animal's condition. 
(c)  The city permits fostering of appropriate animals, and fostering is preferred for females and their litters. The goal of fostering is to provide the animal with a suitable protective environment that may, when necessary, provide rehabilitation. Any animal impounded by an animal control or police officer, surrendered by an owner to the animal control shelter, or found at large and delivered to the animal shelter may be fostered on the first day after the required documentation has been completed; provided, however, that the foster parent or agency must be in good standing with and approved as an animal fosterer by the city's animal control division, and fostering is acknowledged to be temporary. If the owner of the animal is located, the animal may be redeemed by the owner in the same manner provided in this chapter for all impounded animals 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-7; Ord. No. 1515, § 2; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 10, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-90. - Impoundment or destruction of certain animals that bite or injure person. 
(a)  It is the duty of the animal control officer to take into his possession any animal capable of carrying or transmitting rabies or other disease when said animal bites or otherwise injures a person or is suspected of having rabies. The animal shall be impounded for a period of ten days at either the shelter or a licensed veterinarian's hospital for the purpose of observation. 
(b)  If the animal is impossible to capture, it shall be destroyed, and the animal control officer shall use the procedure as established at that time. 
(c)  If the animal is determined to be potentially infected with rabies or any other disease it shall immediately be euthanized and disposed of by the animal control officer. If the animal is determined not to be infected with rabies or any other disease then the owner thereof, by requesting possession of the animal and agreeing to pay the costs of keeping said animal while in quarantine, shall be given possession of the animal. 
(d)  If the owner fails to request possession of the animal within 15 days after it is taken into quarantine and confinement, the animal shall be delivered to the animal control officer for disposition in the same manner as provided for other impounded animals. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-9; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 6, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-91. - Running at large prohibited. 
The animal control officer or any law enforcement officer is authorized to kill an animal at large that is believed to be rabid or that otherwise presents an immediate threat to the safety of the officer or to public safety generally. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-13; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Sec. 8-92. - Animals that die within ten days after injuring a person. 
(a)  Should any animal bite, scratch, or inflict by other means, an open wound in a human being, and thereafter die for any reason within ten days, the owner of that animal must notify animal control and secure an examination of the animal's head by an authorized agency of the city, county, or state qualified to give such examinations. 
(b)  The head of the animal shall be delivered to such examining agency within three hours of death if death occurs between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. and within 12 hours of death if the death occurs between 6:01 p.m. and 4:59 a.m. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the examination report, the results must be transmitted to the person bitten, or if such person is a minor, to the minor's parent, guardian or other authorized adult relative. 
(d)  If an animal subject to this section dies while impounded at the shelter, the animal control officer shall follow the procedure provided in this section. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-16)  
Sec. 8-93. - Proof of ownership, license and vaccination required. 
(a)  Before release of an impounded animal, the animal control officer shall determine to his satisfaction that the person claiming to be the owner of the animal is the owner. In making such determination, the animal control officer is authorized to make such inquiry as may in his discretion be necessary. 
(b)  The animal control officer may require the claimant to submit an affidavit stating that he is the true and lawful owner of such animal and has been so for a stated duration. The animal control officer may also require the claimant to produce witnesses to attest to ownership, either verbally or in writing. 
(c)  Claimants must also provide proof of a current city animal license and current rabies vaccination. If unable to do so, the fees for license, vaccination or both must be paid before the release of the animal. The vaccination fee may be refunded to the claimant if, not later than 30 days from the date of release of the animal, he presents proof of vaccination. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-10; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Secs. 8-94—8-112. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ADOPTION 
 
Sec. 8-113. - Procedure and requirements. 
Any person wishing to adopt an animal from the animal shelter shall pay an adoption fee in the amount provided by the city council and sign an agreement to have the animal sterilized if not already altered. If the animal is not altered within 30 days of the date of adoption, the animal must be returned to the shelter, and there shall be no refund of the adoption or other fees. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-8; Ord. No. 98-16, 9-21-1998; Ord. No. 12-05, 2-20-2012; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 11, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-114. - Written report from veterinarian for extension. 
Upon presentation of a written report from a licensed veterinarian stating that the life or health of an adopted animal may be jeopardized by surgery, the city shall grant a 30-day extension of the period within which the spay or neuter surgery would otherwise be required. Further extensions may be granted upon additional veterinary reports stating their necessity. 
(Code 2012, § 3-8-4; Ord. No. 1808, 9-11-1986)  
Secs. 8-115—8-141. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CARE AND CONTROL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 8-142. - Nuisance animals prohibited; penalties. 
No person shall keep, possess or harbor any animal within the city limits that is a public nuisance or that annoys or disturbs the peace and quiet of any neighborhood, family or person. It is the intent of this article to restrict the privilege of keeping, possessing, owning or harboring an animal within said city to those of a quiet and peaceful nature. Violations of this section shall be punishable by a fine as provided in this chapter and, upon order of the municipal judge, the person having control of the animal may be required to surrender the animal for the purpose of destruction or other disposition. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-12; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Sec. 8-143. - Nuisance dogs. 
(a)  No person shall keep, possess or harbor a nuisance dog within the city limits. Nuisance dogs include the following occurrences: 
(1)  When three or more dogs congregate on any private property without the consent of the owner or occupant and annoy such owner or occupant. 
(2)  When any dog scratches or digs into or tramps on or over any flowerbed, garden, tilled soil, vines, shrubbery, or small plants. 
(3)  When any dog habitually prowls around on any private property to the annoyance of the owner or occupant of the property. 
(4)  When any dog goes into any garbage can or other waste vessel, or turns the same over or scatters the contents of same on the ground around it. 
(b)  Any owner or occupant of any premises who is annoyed by a nuisance dog shall give written notice to the owner of such dog or dogs. Such notice shall be in writing, requiring such owner or person in possession of such dog or dogs, describing each dog, to prevent and abate such nuisance within 30 days, and a copy of such notice shall be delivered to the animal control officer. The notice shall expire 30 days from the date of its delivery to the animal owner or to the animal control officer, whichever is later. 
(c)  If the nuisance is abated by the animal owner within the 30-day notice period, the complainant or the animal owner both shall notify the animal control officer immediately and the issue shall be deemed resolved. 
(d)  If the nuisance is not abated with the 30-day notice period, the animal control officer shall be notified and shall investigate the situation to determine whether, in his opinion, the nuisance continues unabated after proper notice. If the investigation reveals that a nuisance exists, then all dogs described in the notice shall be impounded. It shall be the duty of the impounding officer to withhold the dog for a period of one day within which time the complainant shall file his complaint against the owner of such dog or dogs in the municipal court, charging such defendant with maintaining a private nuisance in violation of the city ordinances. 
(e)  In case of such complaint being filed, the judge of the court shall require that defendant appear and show cause at a time and place named therein why such nuisance should not be abated and prevented. If the court shall find that the nuisance exists in fact, it shall be his duty to turn over the dog or dogs to the impounding officer to dispose of as in other cases provided for the impounding of dogs; provided, however, the owner or person in possession shall have such dog returned on payment of $100.00, conditioned that he will abate, prevent and remove such nuisance for a period of one year from the date thereof. 
(f)  If the court shall find that no nuisance exists as herein defined, he shall deliver the dog or dogs to the defendant and shall tax all costs to the complainant. No proceedings shall be taken as authorized by this section, unless and until the complainant shall make a cash deposit in the amount provided in the fee schedule to cover all costs. 
(Code 1972, § 13-22; Code 2012, § 13-5-1; Ord. No. 2011-10, 5-2-2011)  
Sec. 8-144. - Neglect, abandonment and cruelty prohibited. 
(a)  No owner shall fail to provide their animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather and with humane care and treatment. 
(b)  No person shall beat, cruelly ill-treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal. 
(c)  No person shall abandon an animal. 
(d)  No performing animal exhibition or circus shall be permitted in which animals are induced or encouraged to perform through the use of chemical, mechanical, electrical or manual devices in a manner which will cause or is likely to cause physical injury or suffering. 
(e)  No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that the same shall be liable to harm or be eaten by any pet or livestock. This is not meant to apply to rodent poisons on a person's own property. 
(f)  No person shall indecently exhibit or cause the indecent exhibition of any animal, or let or cause to let any animal to an animal of the opposite sex for sexual intercourse, unless the same shall be in some enclosed place entirely out of public view. 
(g)  No animal shall be left to exposed weather without proper shelter. 
(h)  Shelters for dogs or cats shall consist of a moisture-proof and wind-proof structure of suitable size to accommodate the animal and to allow retention of body heat. It shall be made of durable material, and shall be provided with sufficient quality and quantity of suitable bedding material to provide insulation and protection against cold and dampness and to promote retention of body heat. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-14; Ord. No. 1515, § 1; Ord. No. 91-5; Ord. No. 2002-13, 3-4-2002)  
Sec. 8-145. - Number of dogs and cats per household restricted. 
(a)  No persons shall harbor or keep dogs or cats totaling more than three of each over the age of six months in any household except that if all animals are sterilized the owner may keep in one household to a total of six dogs and cats in any combination. The owner or occupant shall be held responsible for any such violation of this section by any of the members of such household. 
(b)  This section does not apply to households that are issued a kennel license which may harbor or keep dogs and cats totaling more than four over the age of six months. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-4; Ord. No. 1515, § 2; Ord. No. 91-4, 2-14-1991; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-146. - Animals at large presumed abandoned. 
Any animal found at largeis presumed abandoned and may be impounded by the city. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-5)  
Sec. 8-147. - Animal waste. 
The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by his animal on public walks, recreation areas or private property. 
(Code 2012, § 3-1-15; Ord. No. 1515, § 1)  
Sec. 8-148. - Animals to be vaccinated. 
The owners or keepers of animals that are generally required, as a matter of common veterinary practice, to be vaccinated for rabies in the city are required to have their animals vaccinated against rabies. Rabies vaccine shall be recognized for the duration of the vaccine used, i.e., vaccines with a labeled duration of one year, two years or three years will be recognized for one year, two years or three years, respectively. The veterinarian, or other person legally authorized to immunize animals, shall furnish the owner with a certificate of vaccination. The vaccination shall be given and a rabies certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian, anti-rabies clinic, authorized city animal control officer or recognized nonprofit society dedicated to the care and protection of animals. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-3; Ord. No. 1515, § 2; Ord. No. 93-1, 1-4-1993; Ord. No. 2006-19, 8-7-2006)  
Sec. 8-149. - Dogs to be restrained. 
All dogs shall be kept under restraint by secure enclosure or leash. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-4; Ord. No. 1515, § 2; Ord. No. 91-4, 2-14-1991; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-150. - Confining animals to motor vehicles prohibited; removal authorized. 
No animal shall be confined within or on a motor vehicle at any location under such conditions as may endanger the health or well-being of the animal, including, but not limited to, extreme hot or cold temperature, lack of food or water, unattended or confinement with dangerous animals. Animal control officers and police officers are authorized to remove any animal from a motor vehicle at any location when the officer reasonably believes it is confined in violation of this section. Any animal so removed shall be delivered to the city animal shelter after the removing officer leaves written notice in a conspicuous, secure location or within the vehicle of such removal and delivery including the officer's name. No officer shall be held criminally or civilly liable for action pursuant to this section provided the officer acts in good faith, on probable cause and without malice. 
(Code 2012, § 3-11-1; Ord. No. 98-16, 9-21-1998)  
Sec. 8-151. - Fowl. 
A permit is required for the keeping of fowl within the city limits. In addition, fowl must be kept under restraint in a suitable enclosure, with a ground area not less than 200 square feet for each five fowl. No part of the enclosure may be within 50 feet of any residence, including that of the owner. All coops, houses and roosts must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and be disinfected in such manner and to the extent necessary to prevent odors or unsanitary conditions. 
(Code 2012, § 3-4-1; Ord. No. 94-12, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 15, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-152. - Small mammals. 
A permit is required for the keeping of small mammals, including, without limitation, rabbits, rodents (including gerbils, mice, rats, chinchillas, squirrels, guinea pigs, hamsters), ferrets and similar animals, within the city limits. In addition, small mammals must be kept in a suitable enclosure, no part of which may be within 50 feet of any residence, including that of the owner. All enclosures shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and be disinfected in such manner and to the extent necessary to prevent odors or unsanitary conditions. 
(Code 2012, § 3-5-1; Ord. No. 1515, § 5; Ord. No. 94-12, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 16, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-153. - Reptiles; bees and other insects. 
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to own, possess or harbor bees, snakes and other insects or reptiles that may become a nuisance or threat to any person or persons residing within the city except that bees, kept in beehives, may be kept in nonresidential zoning districts provided control of all hives is strictly maintained. 
(Code 2012, § 3-5-2; Ord. No. 1515, 6; Ord. No. 92-26, 11-16-1992)  
Sec. 8-154. - Wild or exotic animals. 
No person shall keep and maintain, or allow to be kept or maintained any exotic or native wildlife animal. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Duly authorized and licensed circuses or educational institutions. 
(2)  Agents or employees properly authorized by an educational institution to keep and maintain that institution's animals in connection with any lawful experimental or research program. 
(3)  Zoological gardens. 
(4)  Zoos that are supervised and publicly maintained. 
(Code 2012, § 3-10-1)  
Sec. 8-155. - Disposal of animal carcasses; surrender of animals to animal shelter. 
(a)  It is the duty of each animal owner to properly dispose of each animal carcass. Within one day of death, the animal carcass shall be buried outside the city limits or disposed of in a manner approved by the county/state health officer. The city may accept carcasses of small domestic animals for disposal and shall charge for services rendered in the amount established by the city council. 
(b)  Live small domesticated animals may be surrendered to the animal shelter for holding and disposal for a fee established by the city council. 
(Code 2012, § 3-6-1; Ord. No. 1515, § 7; Ord. No. 90-26, 12-20-1990; Ord. No. 91-7, 2-7-1991; Ord. No. 98-16, 9-21-1998; Ord. No. 2003-05, 5-19-2003; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 17, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-156. - Kennel minimum standards. 
(a)  All kennels within the city limits shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  The kennel floor shall be made of concrete at least four inches thick, with a smooth surface which shall have one-quarter inch of a slope per foot of fall for drainage. The drainage shall be connected to the sanitary sewage line. 
(2)  Each animal cage shall have sleeping quarters and a lounging area; provided, however, that cat cages shall be completely enclosed. Sleeping quarters for the animals shall be protected from the weather, and each lounging area shall be individually enclosed by chainlink material of at least ten to 14 gauge and shall have the following minimum dimensions for the number of animals to be accommodated: 
Width 	Length 	Height 	Accommodation for: 
4 feet 	12 feet 	6 feet 	Lounging area for one large dog, or two medium dogs, or three small cats 
4 feet 	6 feet 	3 feet 	Sleeping area for one large dog, or two medium dogs, or three small dogs or cats 
 
For the purpose of this section only, small dogs are dogs weighing 25 pounds or less; medium dogs are dogs weighing between 25 and 50 pounds, and large dogs are dogs weighing in excess of 50 pounds. 
(3)  There shall be at least one cage, which must be completely enclosed to house female dogs in heat. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to kennels operated and maintained by licensed veterinarians, to commercial pet stores where all animals are kept within the establishment, nor to animal shelters. 
(Code 2012, § 3-9-2)  
Secs. 8-157—8-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LIVESTOCK 
 
Sec. 8-181. - Permits required for keeping. 
Permits are required to keep livestock in the city limits except livestock maintained in agricultural zoning districts. In addition, livestock other than horses, mules, cattle, sheep, and goats shall not be kept within the city limits except as otherwise provided in this division. 
(1)  Sheep, female (nanny) goats, pot-bellied pigs, grain-fed hogs, and miniature livestock may be kept within the city limits but only in strict compliance with this division. Male (billy) goats and trash fed hogs are not permitted. 
(2)  All livestock shall be kept under restraint in a suitable enclosure, erected with a ground area of not less than one acre for each animal. No part of the enclosure shall be within 50 feet of any residence, including that of the owner. 
(3)  The lot and stables wherein the animals are kept shall be maintained in a clean condition and free from filth at all times. 
(4)  All applicable zoning district requirements shall be met. 
(Code 2012, § 3-3-1; Ord. No. 93-4, 1-4-1993; Ord. No. 94-12, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 2003-05, 5-19-2003); Ord. No. 2013-15, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 13, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-182. - Keeping of horses restricted; keeping of llamas, swine and miniature livestock prohibited. 
Horses are permitted within the city limits only to the extent allowed by city zoning regulations. Swine (including, but not limited to, pot-bellied pigs, goats, miniature horses and other mini-livestock animals) and llamas may not be kept within the city limits.  
Sec. 8-183. - Grain-fed hogs permitted; restrictions. 
(a)  The keeping of not more than ten grain-fed hogs over 25 pounds within the city is allowed by permit. No trash-fed hogs are permitted. 
(b)  The premises where the hogs are kept must be agriculturally zoned and include no less than 40 contiguous acres. 
(c)  Hogs must be kept in a suitable enclosure. No part of the enclosure may be within 100 feet of any residence, including that of the owner, and must be not less than 100 feet from any property line adjacent to nonresidential zoned property and 200 feet from any property line adjacent to residential zoned property. 
(d)  The lot and stables or other enclosures in which the hogs are kept shall be maintained in a clean condition and free from filth at all times. 
(Code 2012, § 3-3-4(C); Ord. No. 94-12, 9-6-1994; Ord. No. 2013-15, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 14, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-184. - Livestock at large; impoundment and sale. 
(a)  The animal control officer shall take up and impound any livestock found running at large within the city limits in violation of any ordinance provision and shall proceed to sell the animal so impounded at public auction for cash by giving five days public notice of the time, terms and place of the sale by posting three written or printed notices in three public places in the city, describing the animal impounded and stating that the same will be sold to defray cost, if not reclaimed. 
(b)  Between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on the day of sale, the animal control officer shall sell the animal at public auction at the place of sale designated in the notice. 
(c)  After deducting all expenses of taking up and keeping such animal, including the feeding and sale of such animal, the balance of the proceeds, if any, shall be returned to the owner of the animal, if known. If no owner files a claim for the balance within 90 days from the date of sale, the funds shall be deemed city funds. 
(Code 2012, § 3-3-2; Ord. No. 1515, § 3)  
Sec. 8-185. - Redemption of impounded livestock. 
The owner of any animal impounded may redeem the same: 
(1)  Before sale, by paying the expenses of taking up and keeping, together with the costs of advertising, if any, and the fees for taking up, impounding, caring for and selling animals shall be determined from time to time by the city manager and approved by the city council; or 
(2)  Within 30 days after sale, by paying the purchaser double the amount paid him for such animal or animals, and his reasonable expense for keeping the same. 
(Code 2012, § 3-3-3; Ord. No. 1515, § 3)  
Secs. 8-186—8-210. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DANGEROUS AND VICIOUS ANIMALS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 8-211. - Keeping of dangerous or vicious animals prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to own, harbor, shelter, keep, possess, or allow to remain on any premises under his control within the city a dangerous or vicious animal. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(A)(1); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Secs. 8-212—8-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE FOR DETERMINATION 
 
Sec. 8-231. - Complaint. 
Any person who has actual knowledge of a dog or other animal may file a complaint in municipal court alleging that the dog or other animal is potentially vicious, potentially dangerous, vicious, or dangerous. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(B)(1); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-232. - Surrender of animal required upon filing of complaint. 
When a complaint is filed in the municipal court of the city alleging violation of this article, the person against whom the complaint is filed, or any other person having control or custody of the animal alleged to be vicious or dangerous, shall deliver the animal to the animal control officer or the duly appointed representative for confinement in the city animal shelter, pending the judgment of the municipal court. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(A)(2); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-233. - Complaints against animals previously deemed potentially dangerous or vicious. 
After an animal has been determined in writing to be potentially vicious or potentially dangerous, further complaints against that animal will be treated as complaints that the animal is dangerous or vicious. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(A)(3); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-234. - Investigation. 
An animal control officer or a commissioned police officer shall investigate complaints of dangerous, vicious, potentially dangerous, or potentially vicious animals and make a determination of the facts. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(B); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-235. - Determination by officer that animal is dangerous or vicious; appeal. 
(a)  Finding; notice to animal owner. If the officer observes an animal that is the subject of the complaint and is witness to dangerous, vicious, potentially dangerous or potentially vicious behavior, he shall notify the owner of the animal in writing that he has determined the dog to be dangerous, vicious, or potentially dangerous or vicious. The notification shall direct that the owner register the potentially dangerous or vicious animal with the animal control officer and comply with all the provisions of this article within 30 days of the date of the notice or, if appropriate, that the owner remove the dangerous or vicious animal immediately and permanently from the city limits within seven days of the date of the notice. 
(b)  Notice to property owner. The officer shall also provide a copy of the written notice to the owner of the property, if other than the owner of the animal. 
(c)  Appeal. Any person whose animal is determined to be dangerous, vicious, potentially dangerous or potentially vicious by the animal control officer or commissioned police officer may appeal the determination by filing a written appeal to the municipal judge within 15 days of receipt of the officer's notice. 
(d)  Hearing on appeal; notice to animal owner. The municipal judge shall hold a hearing within 15 days of the date of the appeal to determine if the animal is vicious, dangerous, potentially dangerous or potentially vicious and whether the animals should be destroyed. The court's decision is final. The animal control officer shall notify the appellant in writing of the decision. 
(e)  Time for owner to comply following ruling. Upon a ruling that the animal is vicious or dangerous, the court shall order that the animal be removed from the city limits within seven days. Upon a ruling that the animal is potentially dangerous or potentially vicious, the court shall order the owner or possessor to comply with the provisions of this article within 30 days. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(B); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-236. - When officer is unable to make determination; judicial proceedings. 
(a)  Request for hearing. If the animal control officer or a commissioned police officer is unable to make a determination that the animal is vicious, dangerous, potentially dangerous or potentially vicious, the complainant may request a hearing before the municipal judge. The request shall be in writing. 
(b)  Hearing. Within 15 days of the request for hearing, the municipal judge shall hold a hearing and shall make a determination as to whether the animal is vicious, dangerous, potentially dangerous or potentially vicious and whether the animals should be destroyed. The court's decision is final. The animal control officer shall notify the appellant in writing of the decision. 
(c)  Time for owner to comply following final order. Upon a ruling that the animal is vicious, dangerous, potentially dangerous, or potentially vicious, the judge shall order that the owner comply with the requirements of this article within 30 days of the order. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(B); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Secs. 8-237—8-265. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - KEEPING POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS OR POTENTIALLY VICIOUS ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 8-266. - Confinement. 
(a)  All potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals shall be securely confined in a securely enclosed and locked pen or kennel with at least 150 square feet of space for each animal kept therein, except when leashed and muzzled as provided in this division. The pen, kennel, or structure must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. 
(b)  All structures used to confine potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must be locked with a key or combination lock when such animals are within the structure. Such structure must have a secure bottom or floor attached to the sides of the pen and must be embedded in the ground no less than two feet. 
(c)  All structures erected to house potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city. All such structures must be adequately lighted, ventilated, and kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(1); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-267. - Leash and muzzle. 
No person shall permit a potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal to go outside its kennel or pen unless such animal is securely leashed with a leash no longer than four feet in length and under the physical restraint of a responsible person over 16 years of age. Such animals may not be leashed to inanimate objects such as trees, posts, buildings, etc. In addition, all animals on a leash outside the animal's kennel must be muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent such animal from biting persons or other animals. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(2); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-268. - Sight proof fencing. 
The yard where a potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal is kept shall be enclosed with a six foot high sight proof fence. The fence shall be maintained in a strong and sturdy condition at all times so that the potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal cannot escape from the property, shall be free of holes, shall not contain any gap between the fence and the ground large enough for a human limb or other animal to go through, and shall be maintained to prevent children and other animals from entering the property where the animal is kept. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(3); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-269. - Signs. 
All owners, keepers or harborers of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must, within 30 days of notification, display in a prominent place of their premises a sign easily readable by the public using the words "beware of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal." In addition, a similar sign is required to be posted on the kennel or pen of such animals. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(4); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-270. - Insurance. 
All owners, keepers or harborers of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must, within 30 days of notification, provide proof to the animal control officer of public liability insurance in a single incident amount of $100,000.00 for bodily injury to or death of any person or persons or for damage to property owned by any persons which may result from the ownership, keeping or maintenance of such animal. Such insurance policy shall provide that no cancellation of the policy will be made unless ten days written notice is first given to the city. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(5); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-271. - Identification photographs. 
All owners, keepers or harborers of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must, within 30 days of notification, provide to the animal control officer two color photographs at least three inches by five inches in size, of the potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals clearly showing the color and approximate size of the animal. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(6); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-272. - Electronic identification tag. 
All owners, keepers, or harborers of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must, within 30 days of notification, have an electronic identification chip installed on the animal. The chip shall be installed by a veterinarian licensed in the this state and shall be readable with the use of an industry standard universal reader. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(7); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-273. - Reporting. 
All owners, keepers, or harborers of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must within 30 days of the incident report in writing to the animal control officer the removal from the city or death of the animal, the birth of offspring of the animal, and the new address of the animal should the owner move from one location to another within the corporate city limits. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(8); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-274. - Sale or transfer of ownership prohibited. 
No person shall sell, barter or in any other way dispose of a potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal within the city to any person within the city unless the recipient personally resides permanently in the same household and on the same premises as the owner of such animal. Such animals may be sold to persons who reside and who will keep the animal outside the city limits. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(9); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-275. - Breeding. 
It is unlawful to breed any potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals within the city. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(10); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-276. - Offspring. 
All offspring born of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals registered within the city must be removed from the city within six weeks of the birth of such animal. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(11); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-277. - Sterilization. 
All owners, keepers, or harborers of potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals must, within 30 days of notification, have them sterilized. Sterilization shall be performed by a veterinarian licensed in this state. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(12); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-278. - Annual registration. 
All potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animals shall be registered by the owner with the animal control officer of the city within 30 days of notification by the animal control officer that the animal has been declared potentially dangerous or potentially vicious. The animal control officer shall not register such animal if the requirements of this division are not complied with at the time of application. The annual registration fee shall be established by the city council. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(13); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Sec. 8-279. - Failure to comply; penalties and other remedies. 
It is unlawful for the owner, keeper, or harborer of a potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal in the city to fail to comply with the requirements and conditions set forth in this division. Any potentially dangerous or potentially vicious animal found to be in the subject of a violation of this division shall be subject to immediate seizure and impoundment. All expenses associated with the impounding, including shelter, food, handling and veterinary care, shall be borne by the owner of such animal during the period of impoundment. Failure to comply with all the requirements and conditions set forth in this division within 15 days of impoundment will result in the destruction of this animal. 
(Code 2012, § 3-2-2(C)(14); Ord. No. 2007-13, 10-1-2007; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 8, 4-6-2015)  
Secs. 8-280—8-290. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ANIMAL RESTRAINT RESTRICTIONS 
 
Sec. 8-291. - Tethering restrictions. 
(a)  Tethering of dogs and cats as a primary means of confinement is prohibited. 
(1)  A single, stationary tethering system may be used as a temporary means of confinement while an animal is actively participating in or attending an organized show, field's trail, agility event, herding contest, or other similar exposition or event of a limited duration that involves the judging or evaluation of animals. 
(2)  A single, stationary tethering system may also be used on an owner's property as a temporary means of confinement while the owner/occupant is present at the residence if the animal being temporarily confined has free and unimpeded access to shelter, food, and water. 
(b)  Animals secured to a single, temporary, stationary tethering system shall not be allowed to be within 15 feet of any sidewalk, street, driveway, front door, or any other passageway used for deliveries or by the public. 
(c)  In the event an animal is temporarily tethered as allowed by this section, the tethering system shall be of a screw in, spiral anchor ground stake type no less than 12 inches in length. Furthermore, the tether and anchor must have a swivel on both ends. 
(d)  Pinch, prong, or choke type collars of any kind shall not be used as a collar on a dog that is being kept on a tether, trolley system, [or] leash while walking the animal or while temporarily at a field or trial show. 
(1)  All collars used must be made of nylon, leather, or other durable, non-metallic material and must be fitted so as to not cause injury to the animal or embed itself in the animal's neck. 
(e)  Neither a chain nor a heavy braided nylon rope may be used to secure an animal in any way. 
(f)  Temporary tethering system leads must be a plastic coated airplane type cable or its equivalent. 
(g)  Tethering shall not be construed to mean including a leash or lead to walk an animal. 
(h)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement K-9s. 
(Ord. No. 2016-08 , § II, 4-4-2016)  
Sec. 8-292. - Trolley system. 
Fastening a dog to a trolley system is permissible if under these circumstances: 
(1)  The primary usable trolley runner line must be suspended at least three feet above the animals head while the animal is standing with at least ten feet in length between two pulley stop points. 
(2)  The secondary line, attached to the animal, shall have a rolling trolley freely movable a distance of at least ten feet on the primary trolley line. 
(3)  The trolley system shall allow the animal unrestricted body movement and utilization of the entire area designated by the trolley system, with a minimum of five feet lateral movement for the animal on each side of the primary trolley line, as measured on the ground. 
(4)  The trolley system must allow the animal free access to food, water, and shelter. 
(5)  The trolley system must be of appropriate configuration to prevent escape of the animal, and confine the animal to the owner's property. 
(6)  The primary trolley line shall be used to restrain only one animal at a time. 
(7)  The dog shall not be fastened outside to a trolley system during a period of extreme weather, including but not limited to, extreme heat or near-freezing temperatures, thunderstorms, or tornadoes. 
(8)  No person shall fasten any dog outside to a trolley system unless the animal has been spayed/neutered. An animal control officer or police officer of the city, upon seeing an animal attached to a trolley system, may enter the open property to view the animal to determine whether or not it is spayed/neutered. 
(9)  No dog secured to a trolley system shall be allowed to be within 15 feet of any sidewalk, street, driveway, front door, or any other passageway used for deliveries or by the public 
(10)  Pinch, prong or choke type collars of any kind shall not be used as a collar on a dog that is being kept on a trolley system. 
(11)  All dogs attached to a trolley system must be secured via a properly fitted, buckle-type collar or body harness of a size appropriate for the animal. 
(12)  All collars and harnesses used must be made of nylon, leather, or other durable, non-metallic material and must be fitted so as to not cause injury to the animal or embed itself in the animal's neck. 
(13)  The trolley system must allow emergency services personnel (e.g., police and fire department) free and unimpeded access to the front door of the residence. 
(14)  The minimum requirements of a trolley system as defined by this chapter are as follows: Round, steel painted poles able to maintain a clean painted surface, of at least a three-inch inside diameter having between 3/16 and 1/4 wall thickness, screw eyes double nutted on the opposite side of the eye to secure the primary trolley runner line, permanently attached caps at the top of the poles to prevent insect infestation and each pole being permanently secured into the ground using a concrete mixture and having been buried no less than 24 inches in depth. 
(Ord. No. 2016-08 , § II, 4-4-2016)  
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person who shall engage in any business, trade, or vocation for which a license, permit, certificate, or registration is required by this chapter, without having a valid license, permit, certificate, or certificate of registration as required, or who shall fail to do anything required by this chapter or by any code adopted by this chapter, or who shall otherwise violate any provision of this chapter or of any code adopted by this chapter, or who shall violate any lawful regulation or order made by any of the officers provided for in this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not to exceed the maximum amount allowed by law for non-jury trials and court costs. Each day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Conviction for such offense may be considered at a hearing on denial or revocation of a license, permit, certificate or certificate of registration held pursuant to section 12-25. 
(Code 2012, § 4-11-1; Ord. No. 2010-18, 12-6-2010)  
Sec. 10-2. - Other remedies for violation. 
No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the right of the city also to apply to the proper courts of the state for a mandamus, an injunction, or other appropriate action against such person. 
(Code 2012, § 4-11-2)  
Sec. 10-3. - Appeals. 
(a)  Denial of license issuance or renewal and license suspension or revocation. Any applicant aggrieved by the denial of an application for a license, the denial of a license renewal, or the revocation or suspension of a license shall have the right to appeal the decision to the city council. The appeal shall be filed in writing and submitted to the city clerk within 14 calendar days after receipt of notice of the denial, revocation or suspension. The city clerk shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be sent by mail to the last known address of the applicant at least ten days prior to the date set for the hearing. Appeal of the decision and order of the city council shall be in accordance with state law. 
(b)  Decisions of building inspector. An appeal may be taken from the decision of the building inspector made pursuant to this chapter by any person aggrieved. Appeal shall be made by verified written statement of the facts filed in duplicate with the city clerk who shall forward a copy to the building inspector. The appeal shall be heard by the city council at its next regular meeting following the filing of the appeal statement, unless postponed by the council, or may be heard at a special meeting. The decision appealed from shall remain in force and effect until such appeal has been decided by the city council. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Code 1972, § 4-26; Code 2012, §§ 4-1-27, 4-11-3; Ord. No. 2010-18, 12-6-2010)  
Sec. 10-4. - Building inspector. 
The city manager shall appoint the building inspector, and such authorized representatives of the building inspector, as he deems desirable. The building inspector and his authorized representatives may also hold other positions in the city government. The city building inspector of this city shall have the powers, duties and functions prescribed for the building official by this chapter, including adopted construction codes, and the powers, duties and functions of the building inspector may be performed by authorized representatives of the building inspector under his supervision and control. 
(Code 1972, § 4-3; Code 2012, § 4-1-3; Ord. No. 2004-07, 2-16-2004)  
Sec. 10-5. - Electrical-plumbing inspector. 
(a)  The city has established a combination electrical-plumbing inspector position. The combination inspector shall be appointed by the city manager, and shall be paid an annual salary to be set as other administrative salaries are set. The combination inspector shall meet all qualifications as required by the state department of health for municipal plumbing-electrical inspectors. The combination inspector may also act as the mechanical inspector for enforcement of the mechanical code. 
(b)  In addition to any other duties provided in this chapter, the electrical-plumbing inspector shall enforce all laws and ordinances relating to plumbing and electrical installations within the jurisdiction of the city. He shall issue such permits, make such inspections, tests, and registrations, and such recommendations for the denial or revocation of registrations as may be required. He shall investigate complaints against persons who are registered as a plumbing or electrical contractor or who have applied for registration as a contractor, make a written report of the investigation to the city clerk, and mail a copy of the report to the contractor/applicant. 
(Code 1972, §§ 4-43, 4-44; Code 2012, §§ 4-3-2, 4-3-3; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990; Ord. No. 95-17, 11-20-1995; Ord. No. 2010-18, 12-6-2010)  
Sec. 10-6. - Right of entry. 
The building inspector, electrical-plumbing inspector, and mechanical inspector shall have the right and authority to enter any building or premises at any reasonable hour and for any reasonable length of time for the purpose of discharging their duties. 
(Code 1972, § 4-69; Code 2012, § 4-4-14; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990)  
Secs. 10-7—10-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION PERMITS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 10-31. - Plumbing permits. 
No plumbing work is undertaken within the city without a permit therefor from the electrical-plumbing inspector. The electrical-plumbing inspector may, from time to time, provide for replacement of plumbing appliances without a permit being required prior to the work commencing. The electrical-plumbing inspector shall conduct an inspection of all work whether permitted or not. In case a permit is not required, the person, firm or corporation will be responsible for payment of required inspection fees of all work undertaken. The plumbing official shall not issue stamp of approval or otherwise authorize plumbing connection until the provisions of this chapter and the plumbing code of the city have been fully complied with. The amount of the fee shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1972, § 4-54; Code 2012, § 4-3-13; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990)  
Sec. 10-32. - Electrical permits. 
No person shall do, or cause to be done, any interior or exterior, new or initial, wiring or any construction, installation, or alteration of any electrical wiring apparatus or fixtures within the city without first having complied with the provisions of this chapter and without first having obtained a permit for the particular work as required by the electrical code from the electrical official of the city. The electrical-plumbing inspector may, from time to time, provide for replacement of electrical appliances without a permit being required prior to the work commencing. The electrical-plumbing inspector shall conduct an inspection of all work whether permitted or not. In case a permit is not required, the person, firm or corporation will be responsible for payment of required inspection fees of all work undertaken. The electrical official shall not issue stamp of approval or otherwise authorize current connection until the provisions of this chapter and the electrical code of the city have been fully complied with. The amount of fee shall be set by the city council by resolution; provided, however, that an owner of a house in which he permanently resides may perform his own electrical work on the house. This provision pertains to single-family dwellings only. Homeowners, when performing electrical work, must conform to all appropriate electrical codes, permit requirements and inspection fees. 
(Code 2012, §§ 4-6-10, 4-6-11; Ord. No. 1385, xx-xx-xxxx; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990)  
Sec. 10-33. - Mechanical permits; required; fees. 
No mechanical work is undertaken within the city without a permit therefor from the mechanical inspector. The mechanical inspector may, from time to time, provide for replacement of mechanical appliances without a permit being required prior to the work commencing. The mechanical inspector shall conduct an inspection of all work whether permitted or not. In case a permit is not required, the person, firm or corporation will be responsible for payment of required inspection fees of all work undertaken. The mechanical official shall not issue stamp of approval or otherwise authorize connection until the provisions of this chapter and the mechanical code of the city have been fully complied with. The amount of such fee shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1972, § 4-58; Code 2012, § 4-4-2; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990)  
Sec. 10-34. - New or re-roofing permits; required; fees. 
(a)  No new roof installation or re-roofing work is to be undertaken within the city without a permit therefor from the building inspector and/or community development. The building inspector may, from time to time, in the event of an emergency, authorize replacement of roofing without a permit being required prior to the work commencing. The building inspector will conduct an inspection of all work (when required) whether permitted or not. In case a permit is not required, the person, firm or corporation will be responsible for payment of required inspection fees of all work undertaken. The building official will not issue stamp of approval or otherwise authorize occupancy until the provisions of this chapter and the building code of the city have been fully complied with. The amount of such fee shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(b)  No person, on his or her own behalf or on behalf of a roofing firm, shall engage or offer to engage in, by advertisement or otherwise, any roofing work who does not possess a valid and appropriate registration and endorsement from the city and the construction industries board unless otherwise excluded by law. All registrations are nontransferable. 
(c)  The standards of installation for roof installation and re-roofing are the provisions of the building codes—the International Residential Code ("IRC") and the International Building Code ("IBC"), as revised and adopted by the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission pursuant to the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission Act. 
(d)  Violations and penalties are covered by and included under section 10-1 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-20 , § I, 9-6-2016)  
Secs. 10-35—10-54. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 10-55. - Required; application; exceptions. 
No building or other structure shall be built, enlarged or altered without a permit from the building inspector therefor as provided in the applicable approved building codes. Applications for building permits shall be made to the building inspector; and the applicant shall provide such plans, specifications and other data as may be necessary for the building inspector to determine whether the permit shall be issued. No building permit shall be required to construct, move, or locate an accessory storage building of 150 square feet or less provided such building meets the following criteria: 
(1)  No electric, gas, or plumbing shall be extended to serve the building. 
(2)  The building shall be accessory to the main building on the property and be used only for the benefit and use of the occupants of such main building. 
(3)  The building shall be located in the rear yard only. 
(4)  The building shall be moveable such as placed on "skids" and may not be placed on a permanent foundation. 
(5)  No more than one such accessory storage building may be constructed or placed without obtaining a building permit. 
(Code 2012, § 4-1-7; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990; Ord. No. 97-14, 7-21-1997; Ord. No. 2004-07, 2-16-2004)  
Sec. 10-56. - Permits; issuance; contents. 
Every permit shall be issued by the building inspector, and he shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. The permit shall state the name of the owner or contractor to whom the same is issued, and contain an accurate description of the lot, or portion of lot, upon which the building is located or to be located, for which the use or occupancy of the streets or alleys is desired, and shall state upon its face that the issuance and validity is conditioned upon the acceptance of and compliance with all the provisions of the ordinances of the city by the owner of such building and all other persons concerned. 
(Code 1972, § 4-11; Code 2012, § 4-1-12)  
Sec. 10-57. - Conditions for building permits. 
(a)  Platting. No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure on any tract of land which has not been subdivided or platted in accordance with the code of ordinances of the city and filed of record, except as provided herein. 
(b)  Improvements. No building permit shall be issued for any lot prior to the construction of all off-site improvements as are required by the city and which have been accepted by the city except as provided herein. 
(c)  Plot plan. No building permit shall be issued for any development on any tract of land for which a plot plan is required, unless such development is in conformity with the plot plan submitted with the final plat or is in conformity with an amended plot plan which has been re-submitted to the city council and planning commission to ensure compliance with the applicable regulations. All building permits in unplatted areas, except those set out in subsection (e) of this section, shall not be issued unless first considered by the planning commission and approved by the city council. 
(d)  Exceptions to platting requirements. A building permit may be issued when the tract of land on which the permit is sought is defined by metes and bounds description in a deed of conveyance only if all of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  All required street rights-of-way shall have been previously dedicated. 
(2)  All required utility and drainage easements shall have been previously dedicated. 
(3)  All off-site improvements as required are approved by the city council as follows: 
a.  If an existing sanitary sewer line is within 200 feet of the property line, applicant must extend this line to service the property. 
b.  Paving of the street adjacent to the property line according to city standards. 
(e)  Other provisions. Any building permit in an unplatted area which seeks to construct a single-family home on a minimum two and one-half acre tract; or enlarge an existing building; or construct an accessory building may be issued by the city without submitting the application to the city council and planning commission if the applicant has complied with all provisions of this section and city planning, zoning and subdivision requirements. No more than two building permits for single-family homes may be issued to a property owner for adjoining unplatted tracts. 
(Code 2012, § 4-1-8)  
Sec. 10-58. - Permit fees. 
Before any building permit shall be issued, the fee therefor must be paid to the city clerk. The amount of such fees shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 2012, § 4-1-9; Ord. No. 1747, 10-10-1983; Ord. No. 90-30, 12-20-1990)  
Secs. 10-59—10-89. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - USE OF PUBLIC WAYS DURING CONSTRUCTION 
 
Sec. 10-90. - Authorized. 
When necessary or expedient during the construction, alteration or repair of any building, a portion of the adjoining alleys and streets, including the sidewalk space and parking, may be used by the builder for building purposes, but the occupancy and use thereof shall be in strict accordance with the provisions of this article and all other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 4-9; Code 2012, § 4-1-10)  
Sec. 10-91. - Injuries; damages; negligence. 
The use of any alley or street or portion thereof, including the sidewalk and parking space, for the preparation, handling or storage of any building material, earth, rubbish or waste of any character, or for the erection or operation of any derricks, engines or other machinery or apparatus, thereon, or for any other purpose permitted by the provisions of this article, shall be upon the express condition that the owner and contractor or any other person making such use of such street, alley or portion thereof, shall be and are jointly and severally bound to indemnify and save harmless the city from any and all damages, loss, cost or expense or claims for damages arising either directly from such use of such street or alley or portion thereof by such owner and contractor or their agents, servants or employees. 
(Code 1972, § 4-13; Code 2012, § 4-1-14)  
Sec. 10-92. - Street use; permit; application. 
Before any street or alley or portion thereof is used or occupied for building purposes, the owner of the building or proposed building or structure, relating to which such use or occupancy is desired, shall secure a permit therefor from the building inspector, which permit shall not be issued except upon an application in writing signed by such owner or in his name by such agent. Such application shall contain the address of such owners and the name and address of the contractor or other person who will be in charge of the work and shall contain a stipulation that if permit is issued thereon, the privileges granted shall be exercised in strict conformity with the provisions of the ordinances of the city relating thereto, and that such owner agrees to indemnify and save harmless the city from any loss, costs, damages or claims and any and all expenses resulting either directly or indirectly from the use or occupancy of any street or alley hereunder, or from any negligence of such applicant, his servants, agents and employees, or contractors in or about the use or occupancy of the same. The application shall contain an accurate description of the lot or portion of lot upon which the building or proposed building is or will be located and the names of the streets and location of the alleys, the use or occupancy that is desired. 
(Code 1972, § 4-10; Code 2012, § 4-1-11)  
Sec. 10-93. - Permits; duration; revocation. 
(a)  The use of the street or alleys under the provisions of this article shall terminate with the completion of the building, provided continuous work is done on the building or expiration of the permit, whichever shall be used first; but in no case shall a street or alley or any part thereof be used for such purposes longer than nine months without first getting the consent of the building inspector. Any permit may be revoked by the city council, in which event all unearned fees paid therefor shall be returned. 
(b)  Ten days shall be allowed for the removal of material and other obstructions after the completion of the building or notice of revocation is served. 
(c)  All material or other obstructions shall be removed from the alleys and streets within such ten days, unless an extension of time is given by the building inspector. 
(Code 1972, § 4-14; Code 2012, § 4-1-15)  
Sec. 10-94. - Extension of occupancy. 
The portions of any street or alley allowed to be occupied for building purposes by the provisions of this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  The part of the street or sidewalk or parking directly in front of the lot or lots upon which the building is to be erected, and not extending out into the street. 
(2)  No alley shall be occupied or any material be prepared for use there in such a manner or to such an extent as to necessitate closing the alley to public traffic. 
(3)  No building material or other obstructions shall be placed or kept in such a position as to block or obstruct the approach to a railway track. 
(4)  No material or other obstruction shall be placed or kept in such a position as to block or obstruct the approach from the street to any fire hydrant, and in no case shall any obstruction be placed within four feet of such hydrant. 
(5)  No street or alley or part thereof shall be so used or occupied as to damage or destroy any pavement, sidewalk, tree, or fire hydrant, or any other public or private property lawfully occupying any part of the street or alley. 
(Code 1972, § 4-15; Code 2012, § 4-1-16)  
Sec. 10-95. - Adjacent property frontage; use of. 
The street, including parking and sidewalk space adjacent to other property, may be used for storing and handling of material, provided the written consent of the owner of such adjacent property waiving any and all claims for damages against the city therefrom be presented to the building inspector. Use of this frontage shall be restricted and regulated the same as specified in this article for frontage on the lot or lots upon which the building is built. 
(Code 1972, § 4-16; Code 2012, § 4-1-17)  
Sec. 10-96. - Sidewalk; protection. 
(a)  Elevated sidewalks will not be permitted.
